If you've never played it just because it's 'old', you don't know what you're missing out on.'  All of my praise to the 1993 original comes right in to this 2016 masterpiece. Now there really is no excuse not to dive into Hell and slay hoardes of evil to the sounds of wailing guitars and demon screams.   A strong contender for game of the year and a must play.

And we're maybe possibly the original Doom Marine.   You will feel powerful.  Doom.

A videogame in it's purest and best form.  In a day and age in which everyone is hating each other over everything, it's a pleasant suprise to see a developer pull its pants down, shake around to all of the internet and just make a game that is actually not trying to be something it isnt.  DOOM has no real goals.  It does not shove your throat with story during the entire campaign. * It rarely has any other gameplay other than 'kill'. It has no real themes or profound ideas. It lacks depressed lesbian teenagers doing f*ck all.  This, my fellow folk, is a honest to God, 'Shoot everything' experience.  It arms you to the teeth. It throws demons at you. Git Gud or Get Rekt.  This is a game that understands pretentious bullsh*t wont do any good.   It just wants to be a fun as balls to the walls FPS and have you grining your teeth as you kick hell's butt back where it belongs.  DOOM knows what it wants to be, and embraces it to create one of the most enjoyable single players ever crafted and that l ever had the pleasure to play.   It's everything you could have asked for a DOOM title and a tribute to all things awesome. I cannot reccomend it enough. Buy it.     * There IS a lore and it is actually very good , what I mean is that the game never forces you to care about it.

Doom is revelatory. It at once feels both extremely modern and yet firmly identifiable as a classic Doom game. It's its own beast, a brilliant gem of an FPS that shows how much can be done once designers go beyond corridors and stop-and-pop shooting.  It would be easy to call it a throwback, but Doom goes way beyond that. Instead, the designers have taken classical FPS mechanics like locked doors and level-based map design and modernized them. Like the original Doom games, you are acquiring colour-coded keys to open doors, looking for secret areas, and going back and forth across large maps to solve simple puzzles until you can reach the exit, but the great use of vertical space, story progression via voice messages and logs, and ability progression makes Doom a very modern game.  This structure wouldn't mean anything if the moment-to-moment mechanics were poor, but thankfully Doom is a top-class FPS in this area too. Movement is fast and feels precise. There's a lot of jumping and platforming, but judging distances and reachable ledges is never a problem. The combat is simply spectacular. It's fast and frantic, with varied and creative weapons that adhere to what one would expect out of a Doom arsenal and unique enemy types with individual behaviours that encourages specific tactics to defeat them. The 'glory kills' - melee attacks that can be done on severely damaged enemies to create health pickups - encourage the player to take more risks when at low health rather than back off, preventing fights from becoming slower long-range exchanges of gunfire.  The presentation is spectacular. The level of detail is insane and the art design makes use of strong colour choices to accentuate different environments. Industrial bases, Martian deserts, and Hell itself all come alive and exude a sense of place that feels like it extends beyond your monitor. The audio design is fantastic. The sound effects are great, with weapon blasts, demon yells, and voice work all feeling very appropriate. I'm particularly surprised and pleased that Doom doesn't seem to go heavy on the loudness - weapons like the plasma gun are actually fairly quiet but still feel satisfying. It's a nice change from the sheer cacophony of Call of Duty and Battlefield. The music contains audio cues from the original Doom games but never degrades into simply covering existing songs. It's not quite as iconic and hummable as Bobby Prince's soundtracks, but it's very well integrated into the gameplay. The writing is both ridiculously over-the-top and played entirely seriously. Bits ranging from matter-of-fact announcements of demonic presence, to corporate-propaganda-meets-cult recordings being played over the base's PA system, to quasi-Biblical records in Hell that explain the Doom marine's backstory all have their own unique 'voice' and phrasing, and are all enjoyable to listen to. I can't remember the last time I actually stopped moving in a shooter to listen to diegetic dialogue, but I did in Doom. The writers are (rightly) supremely confident in their ability to let the ludicrous nature of the story and setting stand on its own and never succumb to a fourth-wall-breaking reference or an ironic dig at their own worldbuilding. It's a commendable approach, one that respects the player's intelligence.  The only real problem? All of this praise applies only to the singleplayer. Multiplayer is a horrific abomination, a floaty Halo-esque mess without the vehicles, map design, or unique modes that make that game's multiplayer so good.  But that doesn't damage the incredible singleplayer campaign in any way. If you have any interest at all in singleplayer first-person shooters, you simply must play Doom.

Summary

In the Abrahamic religions—and the texts that have grown out of them—Satan is a fallen angel, cast out of heaven for daring to rebel against God. Though his name is synonymous with fear and evil, it’s Satan’s tireless, implacable need to oppose everything God wills that truly characterizes him. He’s a catch-all for the misfortune of heroes and nations. He’s a scoundrel who’s always up to overturn the plans of the master of the universe.   Back in 1993, id Software’s DOOM was another act of rebellion. Created by a small team of industry upstarts, DOOM latched onto Satanic iconography to mark itself as dangerous—a raised middle finger to the authoritarian mainstream of the morally panicked religious right then dominating Western culture and politics. DOOM was meant to feel threatening in both imagery and business. Filled with inverted crosses and goat-headed sigils, splashed with gore, its free “shareware” levels spread like wildfire through the young internet.  Now, more than 20 years later, id has returned to DOOM, reimagining its best-loved creation with a game called, fittingly, DOOM. It’s a difficult proposition not just because nostalgia can be so unkind to revisits, but because, more than anything else, the first DOOM is defined so largely by its attempt to buck tradition—something that a backward-looking reboot can’t replicate.  DOOM certainly has been cooking for a long time, even with fears of it becoming nothing more than a nostalgia trip of what was, but this couldn’t be any more wrong. DOOM is back and it’s not riding off its lineage. To be put simply: you can’t compare DOOM to what we’ve been shown in the trailers. You have to see it, feel it, grab it by its demonic balls and shred them apart to truly experience the hell of DOOM.  Taking place on Mars, once again the UAC (Union Aerospace Corporation) have been quite unfortunate by meddling with powers beyond them trying to harness the power of hell, they inadvertently have unleashed it upon on themselves. This leads to the inhabitants of the facility either being riddled with death or possessed by the spawn of hell. You as Doomguy arise in the wake of this and it’s up to you to put on your best green power armor, grab your trusted guns and rid the menace once and for all. That’s all you need to know about the story, sure there are other moments within to guide you towards to an objective, but you’ll be too busy ripping demons a new one to notice.  Everything that made the original great is here: the map design, the weapons, the demons, even the music are refreshingly realised with a brand new coat of paint for the new generation. From the very get go, you’re thrust right into action. This ain’t no cinematic, follow-the-leader shooter, this is all out action. Each new area you enter welcomes you with tantalising death as you are barraged with hordes of demons. The doors lock out and you’re trapped within. Like small arenas, these rooms fill with a demonic presence or a nest of gore that must be cleansed before proceeding.   This is where the real fun begins as the sheer pounding momentum of metal music and crunching bullets against demonic flesh couldn’t be more exhilarating. You may think they’d become tedious after sometime, but as you progress further and start fighting new types of damnation things get twisted, with all the classics returning: from Imps, Hell Knights, Revenants and Pinkies. Furthermore as you fight your way through, switching up your playstyle you can take advantage of the brutal and satisfying Glory Kill system; it never becomes dull.  Speaking of glory kills - the new Glory Kill system introduced is clearly inspired by the popular Brutal DOOM mod for the original. It makes for a more frantic, up close and personal punishment for the wrath of hell. When you barrage enough bullets into your target, you’ll stagger them and they’ll glow a tint of blue and orange - this is your moment to joyfully rip them apart, crush their skulls and tear their limbs off. Chaining together such brutality in a flurry of combo killing is best described in one word: glorious.  As mentioned before, this is all out action, so when it comes to the weapons; you’re not limited to a couple as your trusted Doomguy has no limits: From the super shotgun, chaingun to the rocket launcher and the iconic BFG9000. The classics are back and they’ve received an upgrade. Each weapon has fierce power behind them, especially the super shotgun, and with the ability to switch weapons on the fly, which briefly slows down time, you’ll be in for a real running and gunning good time. Combined with constant movement, the ability to double jump and mantle objects in the environment everything is based around being quick or be dead.  The demon spawn is no slouch and will hit hard and may even overwhelm you. Keeping an eye on your health and armor can make all the difference. Enemies will drop health and ammo upon death, but searching the environment will give you the advantage. If all else fails, rev up the trusted chainsaw and tear through the demonic plague in a single blow and see them burst into a bloody fury of health and ammo.  The levels are a beautiful, hellish throwback to old-school design. They’re straightforward but non-linear, semi-open areas that you can explore to your heart's content. Just by bringing up the area’s map alone you can see the intricate design. From the blood-soaked metallic walls of the UAC facility to the ritualistic savage foreboding landscape of Hell, it all flows organically, offering more verticality than any other DOOM game, when you’re not killing demons in a furious spree of gunfire, you’ll be using your mantling abilities to traverse the Mars facility or Hell with ease.  With level design such as this, exploration rewards as you seek out not only health, ammo and armor but everyone's favourite: secrets. DOOM offers a variety of hidden goodies. Search hard enough and you’ll come across weapon mods and power armor upgrades - which add new abilities - Ranging from a rocket shot from your shotgun or mini-rockets to your assault rifle, and for your armor gain advantages in combat such as increased weapon switching speed and self damage reduction. They all add more power to your already well-equipped arsenal and are worth seeking out. Runes are also introduced, and are another worth hunting for. They break up the frantic pace by offering short challenges with specific requirements. If you beat the challenge within the given time you’ll be rewarded a demonic rune to further fuel your demon slaying spree.  It all comes together into an unmissable and bloody enjoyable whole; certainly one of the finest shooter campaigns I’ve played through. The same unfortunately can’t be said of the multiplayer component, which isn’t necessarily terrible, but it’s not really good either. There’s nothing on offer here to drag MP fans away from a free alternative like Unreal Tournament. DOOM’s multiplayer was created by an entirely different studio to id Software and it shows. Loadouts are bizarrely a thing, and it leans far too heavily in the direction of both Halo and Call of Duty. The essence of arena shooters is on weapon pickups and holding these key points. Everyone spawning with a rocket launcher kind of ruins and eliminates much of the tactical play.  Doom manages to challenge the conventions of the first-person shooter genre by going back to its roots. It will have you breathing heavily, cursing in frustration, and screaming in triumph. The multiplayer is a bit of a letdown, but the campaign is absolutely glorious. If you're a fan of fast-paced games, or you love classic shooters with great campaigns, you have to play Doom, period.

I played thousands of hours of Doom 1, 2 and custom wads over the years, so naturally I was edgy as hell when it came to the new game. I hated it, I joked about it, made passive-aggressive Steam hub posts about it, implying kids did not know what a good Doom game is about.  I thought id Soft had lost it.  In the end, I bought the game to see what the positive reviews were all about first-hand.  I could go into boring minute details about how the new game could be improved and how it's lacking some important aspects of the originals, but I won't.  id Soft has not lost it. The game is tight, fast and fun, the levels are sprawling and fun when you turn off your compass and obj indicators, it even has a bleeding automap! I understand that you cannot ship Doom 2 with updated animations and textures and sell it to a 2016 audience.  Whatever has been changed to make the game work today is made with deliberation and does not ruin the core experience, which I believe is as close as you can get to the adrenaline thrills of the original games.  Good job, Stratton and team!
Kids play Call of Duty  Guys play Battlefield  Men play Arma  Demon hunters play DOOM.

A very fun and good looking FPS, probably the best of this decade so far.   The singleplayer campaign is definitely the strongest point of this game and it takes a fair amount of time to beat while getting every collectible and secret (a full playthrough took me about 40 hours without rushing, if not more). However, the replayability is somewhat poor unless you care about high scores in the arcade mode. The arsenal is pretty big, with every weapon filling a certain niche and staying useful throughout the entire game thanks to upgrades.  Aside from weapons, you can upgrade your suit to give yourself nice advantages like explosion resistance, improved mobility, longer power-up timers and a more detailed automap. You can buff yourself even further using runes, acquired by beating simple 'rune trials' that are scattered around the game's levels.  Of course, all of the upgrades described above are completely optional and you can keep it vanilla if you want.   Multiplayer is  okay , closer to Halo and Call of Duty than it is to Quake but that doesn't make it bad (unless you're a braindead pseudo-veteran with nostalgia goggles glued to your face). SnapMap is neat, it's nowhere near a proper SDK but considering the way this game's engine (and the extreme DRM) works it's really the best we could get. There's enough features and content to make some decent stuff, you just need to be creative and have enough patience to deal with the wonky controls.  The soundtrack is  absolutely fantastic . From calm ambient tracks to combat themes filled with hard kicks, hellish choirs, heavy metal and lots of vintage Russian synthesizer wizardry: it is powerful, gritty and brutal. It nails the game's atmosphere and fits the gameplay very well, dynamically changing mid-fight, right as you're stomping another poor imp's head into the ground.  To say that DOOM's visuals are just 'good' would be an understatement: the game is beautiful. My PC isn't all that great so I had to keep the graphics pretty low but it's great even on Medium settings, not to mention Ultra and  Nightmare . If you're using one of the newer GPUs, like NVIDIA's 9xx or 10xx series, you can switch the renderer to Vulkan, which will give you a considerable performance boost.  There's a little problem that might turn some people off: this game uses  Denuvo Anti-Tampering , which, in theory, stops pirates, therefore making more sales. Sure, it works, DOOM only got cracked once or twice and the holes were patched since then. Fighting piracy is good and I fully support that, but the way Denuvo does it is too extreme and it ends up hurting the consumer in several ways. One is the complete inability to modify the game. Modding is the reason why the first two Doom games are still alive and well, so it's a shame that the latest entry in the series not only uses a hard to mod engine (look at idtech 5 and RAGE with its whopping  1  mod, idtech 6 isn't too far off) but also one the most harmful and extreme anti-piracy measures ever made.   To sum up, DOOM is a solid, enjoyable FPS experience and I very much recommend buying it just for the amazing singleplayer . The pros greatly outweigh the cons, most of which don't even matter to the average player (mod tools for example).   I could write a bigger and more detailed review with less subjective p!ss but this should be enough, no one reads this stuff anyway.   I'd be lying if I said I didn't do this for the badge.
When I was a child. I imagined the first Doom exactly what it looks like today.

I've been a big fan of the Doom series since I've played 'The Ultimate Doom' for the first time at the age of 6. Now, some 20 years later, I have probably played hundreds of games... but holy hell, never have I witnessed such a comeback! DOOM is what a Doom game should be: An almost plotless, gory and fastpaced shooter with a Heavy Metal soundtrack.  If you're looking for a good story, this game isn't for you. Like every game in the series, DOOM barely has a plot. Our hero doesn't even speak a single word while he rips and tears his way through demonic hordes. It's all about killing demons. And killing demons is so much fun in this game. So if you like dodging fireballs while demon guts are flying left and right as you're cutting an Imp in half with your chainsaw or blasting a hole into a Hell Knight's chest with your Super Shotgun, this game should be right up your alley. You are even able to perform 'glory kills' on wounded enemies. The 'glory kills' seem slightly exaggerated sometimes, the DOOM Marine breaks bones, crushes skulls and literally tears demons apart in a matter of seconds, but they are a really nice addition and greatly improve the flow of the game.  A lot of effort was put into the great and detailed level design, although most levels are rather linear and largely based on arena fights, with some side paths here and there and a lot of secrets. Exploration is often rewarded with suit and weapon upgrades, making you even more effective at killing demons.  While the singleplayer is mostly a return to the roots of FPS games, the multiplayer has a certain 'modern' feel and is quite uncharacteristic for an id Software game, as it features loadouts instead of weapon pickups and unlockable weapon and player skins. It is actually much better than people make it out to be, although it isn't innovative by any means. Several of the powerups found in multiplayer are already known from the Quake series, such as 'Regeneration', 'Quad Damage' or 'Haste'. However, DOOM also features a new powerup called the 'Demon Rune' that transforms you into a demon of your choice when you pick it up. This item adds a lot of fun to the game, but it is often fiercely fought over and you are rarely able to use it yourself.  In this age of Halo and Call of Duty clones, DOOM is like a breath of fresh air with its 'back to the roots' approach. It's nonstop fastpaced action from start to finish. This game is fantastic and probably the best FPS game I've played in recent years.

------------------------------------------------- ORIGINAL REVIEW: This game told me it loved me, made me trust it, and then violently took advantage of me. 10/10 would sacrifice ♥♥♥♥ again ------------------------------------------------- SERIOUS REVIEW UPON COMPLETING CAMPAIGN ON NIGHTMARE: This game is one of the few 'Triple A' titles (of the last three years) to drop and not leave a sour taste in my mouth. I was so nervous that it was going to be all hype...and for once...A game was able to not only live up to expectation(s), but DOOM has successfully exceeded them. The ultimate homage; a hat tip to the Great Grandpappy of the FPS genre.   PROs: +The Level Design+ --- Expansive arena type levels with a focus on the z axis/mobility.  +The Enemies+ --- Hello, you beautiful ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s you.  +The Items+ --- Yes, the items. I can't tell you the last time I was stoked upon seeing a gigantic glowing green shield or chest piece. Would it be DOOM if it didn't have keycards? NO IT WOULDN'T, so you collect red/yellow/blue keycards. CLASSIC. +The Upgrades+ --- You literally punch a drone in the face to unlock mods for your weaponry!! +The 'No-Reload' Aspect+ --- Wouldn't it really suck if six shots into a mob of demon spawn you had to take a knee and reload that shotgun of yours? Yeah, IT WOULD SUCK A*S. DOOM knew that in advance and took the liberty of saying, 'RELOADING IS FOR P*SSIES'. +The Momentum Of Combat+ --- Low on health? You'd better rip and tear your way into the fodder for health and ammo. Glory Kills...tasty, delicious, glory kills. Looking for cover? TOO BAD NERD!(ps. you low on ammo? Chainsaw a motherf*cker and make it rain munition(s)).  +The Implementation of Double Jump+ --- I feel like I shouldn't even need to explain the obvious possibilities of this one...  +The Story+ --- While it won't go down in history as an emotional drama full of interesting character developement and plot twists, it was still satisfying to unlock the little mysteries that are hidden throughout hell/mars. The Dr.'s Voice alone made the story worthwhile. +The Soundtrack+ --- google Mick Gordon, that is all +The Advanced Settings Tab+ --- Get ya nerd on and track your cpu/gpu stats along with your FPS and resource usage in the top right hand corner of your screen. +The Power-Ups+ --- Did I just snag a red orb that allows me to literally rip demons in half/disembowel them with my bare hands? OF COURSE YOU DID! DON'T BE A DUMB B*TCH!  Enough strokin DOOM's Ego, here come the CONs: (many of which are minor and more of personal complaints vs. being game breaking features/functions) - Multiplayer, although it is entertaining at first...it quickly loses it's appeal. - Speaking of multiplayer, why no co-op campaign? FEELS BAD MAN - A few place where you get 'stuck' on BS decorations in the level...I've been murdered by a one inch elevated rock/platform several times. Got stuck 'in' the levels as well a few times throughout the campaign. Nothing too major.  Final Rating for DOOM: 9/10 -- Easily THEE best FPS single player experience I've had in the last 8 years of gaming. I HIGHLY recommend DOOM to any who have given it some thought but experience doubt or hesitation.   Final Words for DOOM: Obviously DOOM attracts a certain type of player...with that being said: If you didn't like the originals, didn't play them at all or don't usually like FPS games, then don't buy this, plain and simple.

It rips out the heart of 90's Doom and and shoves it down a glorious modern game engine. I like that the game doesn't take itself too seriously and just aims to provide a good time. Performance is just awesome on a 960gtx / High / 2560x1080p   Welcome back, Doom Guy.

Hey, remember that game Doom? Remember how it was that one first game that gave you a gun and a first person view of you using said gun to shoot some things? Yeah that game. That game was great. This one is a lot like it.    So, we are back on Mars, some stuff has gone down and it's up to you to do the things you do best - shooting guns and boy do you shoot a lot of guns. Of course all the classics are back and they all feel absolutely fantastic. Fluid firing & reload animations, fast draw speeds, sufficient kickback all contribute to a great experience when using them. All weapons now also offer improvements by means of mods which alter how they work. The shotgun, for example, can have an explosive shot mod which can be improved further with smaller effects allowing you to use it in more than one way. Mods are acquired by reaching certain locations in levels and improvements can be bought with points you rank up through the game and completing challenges. Its all done in an indirect fashion so all these improvements or mods never get in your way and offer some extra fun along the way. Your suit also offers upgrades gained by collecting certain items that boost your passive abilities. Finally runes can be found in the game which port you to a small arena and give you a challenge to complete and on successful completion, unlock and offer you an ability to use (example: survive one deadly hit).    As you may have guessed, this is a first person shooter (no, really.) so core gameplay will revolve around shooting demons. Doom is about  fast paced action  and its gameplay reflects that rather nicely. You move hastily through levels, wield fast switching and responsive weapons and tear through demons like a hot knife through butter. Glory kills are a thing and reward players with ammo and health for grabbing unsuspecting demons by the head and stomping on them like one would stomp in a trash bit to make room for more trash. Headshots pop off heads, shotguns rip apart demons and the chainsaw makes you laugh an evil laugh you did not know you had. Level designs feature futuristic Mars base interiors, complex large maps that follow a linear path but stay open for the most part and open further where large battles take place. This recipe works and stays the same throughout the game but switches the Mars internal base esthetic for red rocks, red sky and hell fire on about 40% of the levels.    Doom is a bit different from its predecessor, Doom 3. Closed claustrophobic and dark corridors are instead replaced by large open well lit environments reflecting the nature of the fast paced shoot em up combat in contrast to the more horror theme Doom 3 was going for. Graphically it has improved tremendously: high quality models and textures provide a high fidelity experience while not necessarily too demanding on the hardware. On a mid range PC, I had the game running on 50-60 FPS on ultra settings at 1080p. Included is a map maker and an arena shooter multiplayer mode that feels as good as any arena shooter would with a coat of Doom on top. The campaign barely offers a story to follow but there is enough there to grease the wheels of this gravy train enough to get it going. 15 hours was my time spent with it.   The bits and pieces of this game work together to make the whole package feel great. 1. Fast paced movement and shooting trough large maps feel fluid. 2. Demon spawns are plentiful and kills reward the player with marvelous gore. 3. Aided by the soundtrack composed by Mick Gordon featuring fast tempo on lower tone guitars and heavy beating drums. I never thought I would like industrial metal so much. The screaming demons on my favorite track, BFG Division, always get me.    DOOM is an ode to the FPS of old, pays homage to its roots and upgrades itself with unlockable mods that only provide more action at the expense of nothing else. If you came looking for a story, look elsewhere. If you are here for action, there is no better place to be.

Pros:  -Great soundtrack -Great level design  -Good variety of weapons  -Decent length  -Brutal as Hell -Super graphics  -You only use violence to interact with your environment -Within 10 seconds you shoot demons  -High replay value   Cons:  -Snapmap is a little too limited for my liking  -Multiplayer is forgettable
DOOM is a horror game where you're the monsters.

This is about as good as a Doom reboot is ever going to get.  Crank up the difficulty and rip and tear!  Full video review:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AOAGjzyrp80   Multiplayer Review:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G4-2gOJDgPM

This is exactly how you make a modern old school style FPS. - Minimal cutscenes. - No parts where you're forced to follow nameless American marine #3 around a level while they spew forgettable dialog and you wait as they open doors, - You can carry more than 2 guns at a time. - Enemies fly apart in to little squishy red gibs when you kill them (Yes folks, GIBS in 2016!) - Hordes of enemies attack you and you have to use your skill to survive because there's no regenerating health or cover. You actually don't even need those things because Doom Guy is made from 100% manly beef and he probably has a full mountain man beard with bits of half chewed bacon stuck in it under his helmet. - No puzzles where you wander around stuck for half an hour because your only motivation is kill the ugly demons and move on so you can kill more ugly demons. - The gameplay isn't interrupted every 10 minutes so a random actor from that TV show you don't watch can tell you something you won't remember anyway.  This game is so manly you will grow hairs on the shaft of your ♥♥♥♥♥.
It is not that you are stuck in a room with 100 monsters, 100 monsters stuck in the room with you. 10\10
I haven't smiled like this while playing a game in a lot of years.
ID took one look at brutal doom and went 'hey, we can do better' and then TOTALLY DID.
this game cured my erectile disfunction. i was rock hard the whole time playing it

Updated review.  A masterpiece of a game and easily contends with Shadow Warrior 2 for the top FPS spot of the year, sure, the multiplayer is trash compared to what it should have been, although still better then quite a few titles. But the single player content makes up for it in aces.   I needed to update this review after I found arcade mode. A stunning addition to the game which adds even more replayability to the game then what it had at release; and serves as an excellent way to train your aim/reflexes to help you get your game up.     ORIGINAL REVIEW.   Very silly, yet shockingly accurate synopsis of the plot.   'We're demons, lords of darkness and such, but then there was this really angry dude and he just angried so hard we couldn't do anything, we turned Satan into Super Mega King Kong Bezzelboss 5000, but this dude just got more angry and ripped his head off. So we stuck him in a box and we just creep around outside it so we don't make him angry.' 'What do you mean someone stole the box!?'   'Hey guys, lets open a portal to hell, what could possibly go wrong?!'  'Hey guys, I found this massive demon, lets cut it's arm off and graft a gun in it's place, what could go wrong!'  'Hmmm... looks like some of my science guys are now skeletons thanks to hell magic, I know! Only cure it to give them jetpacks and shoulder mounted rocket launchers!'  'I don't care if a demon stole your spine, this is the cost of progress and I'm a 3 metre tall robot'   'Doomguy, I ran out of scientists and I need your help.' Punch screen away. 'Doomguy, please carefully discharge the expesi...' Rip out expensive science stuff and kick it.  'I must punch demon now!'

DOOM is a super gory, fast paced action FPS that has an excellent single player campaign, as well as multiplayer.  Check out my  Quick Campaign Review  here:  https://youtu.be/aCy1Hd71tbA  I expected DOOM to be all about the combat, with little to no story. I was very surprised that the story had so much more depth to it than I had anticipated.   As you progress through the campaign, you find several different weapons, and almost all of them are badass. On top of some already awesome weapons, you can also find weapon mods for each one to upgrade how you want. I found the plasma gun stun mod especially helpful for keeping demons off of my face, and the chainsaw and BFG are crazy fun to use. You will need to switch up your weapons as you run out of different ammo types, and you will also want to mix in melee finishers as well.  When demons get low on health they stagger for a short period, and when you see it, if you quickly get into range, you can perform a melee execute called a glory kill. The glory kill animations are bloody as hell, and it’s incredibly awesome each and every time. I haven’t been this satisfied ripping things apart since I played The Darkness II. The kill animations are short, and quick, so I never got sick of seeing them, unlike how bored the slow motion kill shots in the Fallout series got after the first few. Performing glory kills also awards bonus health drops, allowing you stay in the fight longer.  The boss fights each had scripted phases with unique mechanics. Bosses did a lot of damage if you failed to react properly, but once you learned the patterns, the fights were much easier. I really enjoyed the boss fights, It was nice to only have to focus on one enemy for a little bit instead of a whole bunch of them chasing after you.   Pros:

'Over the centuries, mankind has tried many ways of combating the forces of evil... prayer, fasting, good works and so on. Up until Doom, no one seemed to have thought about the double-barrel shotgun. Eat leaden death, demon...'

DOOM (2016) is an id Software game. The above statement may seem strange, but it reflects what I thought while I was playing the game. id Software is a company known for kickstarting the FPS genre, and making gorgeous game engines. Sadly, their latest efforts haven't been as successful as the original Doom and its sequel, or the Quake series. Rage, their first new IP in years, had pacing issues, and idTech 5, id's shiny new engine, wasn't as good as one would expect from id. One could argue that the last id Software game that felt right at home with their legacy is either Doom 3 or Quake 3 Arena (Doom 3 lacks the relentless action that made id famous but it delivered in spades if you consider the tech department)  Well, I have good news for you, fans of the FPS genre! id Software is back, and better than ever. DOOM's singleplayer campaign is both modern and old school. It's incredibly good looking, runs amazingly well, and has a beautiful soundtrack. Gone is the oppressive darkness and slow action that characterized Doom 3. Rage's poor pacing and graphics issues? Gone too. In their place, we can find fast paced action, a well thought upgrade system, intricate maps that remind us of a bygone era, and a tongue in cheek attitude that permeates the whole story mode. Doom Guy is here to kill demons and he won't let silly things like cutscenes get in his way.  Prepare yourself for a journey that will take you to Mars and (spoiler alert, duh!) Hell itself in a quest to blow apart thousands of demons and use their entrails as health or ammo boosts. DOOM adds a new feature called Glory Kills, which lets the player execute wounded demons in exchange for a quick health top up, and believe me, you will learn to love it! So yeah, id Software is back, baby! Now that I've relayed the good news, it's time for the bad stuff: The multiplayer component isn't as good as the campaign, and it wasn't even made by the same team (it was outsourced to the same guys that helped build the latest Halo's online component) Movement is pretty fast, but not as fast as Quake 3. Weapons aren't pickups anymore (with some exceptions) and you build a loadout, similar to Call of Duty or Battlefield, to name a few modern shooters that use the same system. The SnapMap system is interesting, but a fully featured mod suite would certainly be a better thing for PC owners.  All in all, I think that DOOM is one of the best shooters in decades, and any FPS fan should consider getting it. A botched multiplayer offering can't overshadow the fact that the campaign is a work of art and it can rightfully claim a place in history alongside Doom 1 and 2.

I honestly didnt think this game was going to be good. The beta left a bad taste in my mouth and made me think that the game was going to be a huge mess. Boy was i wrong. This is honestly some of the most fun ive had in a single player expeirence in a long time, coming from a person who mostly plays competitive multiplayer games. The multiplayer is okay, but the single player has me on the edge of my seat alot and is a ♥♥♥♥ing blast. Great game so far, although i havent tried the snap map ♥♥♥♥ yet :/   Single Player 9.5/10 Mutiplayer 7.5/10
Even when playing on a potato, this game is really well optimized. Buy this game, it can run on potatoes, so no excuse.

You play as the Doomguy, the same marine who's been fighting demon hordes from the very first Doom game.  By the end of the Doom 64 you've closed the portal to Hell, leaving yourself in the demon realm to keep fighting the hellspawn. After countless years of glorious battles the forces of Evil have finally managed to stop your demon slaying campaign by toppling a freaking cathedral on top of you. Unable to kill you, demons took your unconcious body and encased it into a sarcophagus and put it away into the deepest pocket of Hell dimension.  Fast forward to the beginning of the DOOM (2016). You wake up laying in the open sarcophagus, sirens are blaring, zomblers run amok - looks like a portal to Hell is opened once again... 'Some people never learn,' you think to yourself while standing up and grabbing a pistol: 'it's time to put an end to this Hell invasion, no matter the cost'.  Absolutely beautiful and atmospheric singleplayer campaign with just a few cutscenes but quickpaced and stunningly brutal gameplay. Get the game just for the singleplayer, it absolutely worth it!  Quite solid and fun multiplayer, featuring Hell Runes that can transform you into a blood-thirsty demon and good old pickups such as Quad damage.  Always fresh and fun new levels and challenges are waiting in SnapMap - an in-game level designer that allows to build new missions and even new game modes. Already full to the brim with user-made content SnapMap is giving DOOM the longevity it deserves. Try your hand at it and let your creativity shine - the sky is the limit!

Id Software proved that you can use a classic road to get to present time, without destroying the charm of the original. Doom remains an old-school, dynamic shooter devoid of lengthy cut-scenes and convoluted plot. It's a hell of a ride, just like twenty years ago.

I remember those good old days playing Quake 2... ...or older days playing Quake... ...or the oldest days playing classic DooM series...  That's it. I can feel it. Now I can stop (at least for a while) searching the best graphic mods for q2. Now I can stop (at least for a while) replaying old Doom/Quake games.  This is the future I've been waiting for for so long.
Shedding tears of hate-joy while chainsawing things 4 times my size in half. Buy this game.

Pros, cons and so on are below. But in terms of the campaign, it is probably my favourite fps campaign since F.E.A.R. with an absolutely stunning gameplay loop. Absolutely amazing stuff. I've been enjoying the multiplayer to, which isn't as brilliant as the campaign thus far but is still fun. Certianly not tacked on, but certainly not as good as the campaign.  Pros: + the gameplay loop is just amazing, it does start of slow though, but it picks up pace very quickly. + Runs Great (everything but shadows and Vitual Texturing Page Size maxed as the nightmare setting are not selectable unless you have 5gb of vram. Otherwise maxed and always above 60 with a 970). * by using '+menu_advanced_AllowAllSettings 1' in launch options you can select the higher graphical modes and from an hour or so of playing completely maxed the performance hit isn't massive but it did cause some minor stutter for myself. However if you lock to 60fps this may not be an issue as the game didn't dip below that point). + Guns are varied in use and fun to use. + Fast paced, as in very fast paced though it does start of relatively slow compared to just a little later into the game. + Sprint by default, though you can make your character move slower. + Vartiety has been added with upgrades that add to the chaos. + The game is gorgeous and the levels varied. + The movement system is fantastic. + Whilst no open world the levels are large and expansive. + The verticality in said levels is used brilliantly to enhance the options you have from moment to moment. + Enemies are nicely varied requiring different tactics to take out. Especially when you up the difficulty. + Plenty of secrets and things to look around and find. + Melee attacks are a nice addition that add some tactics for getting health back + Minimal story with very few cutscene like moments so far (yes, doom should not be overly cut scene or lore heavy, it at its core is about killing demons). What is there however is done well, it just isn't front and center. + The voice acting is suprisingly extremely good. There isn't much, but what is there all works as intended. Bravo, it would have been easy to have this let the game down. + Loving the multiplayer, but if you didn't like the beta I can't comment as it may be similar (didn't play much of the beta myself). + Though I wouldn't listen to it on its own, the music fits the game extremely well. Sometime a track will play when it probably shouldn't (common in games) but overall it fits very well. +Snapmap adds a large amount of possible content that so far has been quite good. Though only time will tell how much it is used.   Cons: - Whilst a nice addition to much emphasis is on melee finishers. It is at its worst at the beginning, but I can't help but feel it is something that could have been introduced later once it actually becomes used in a tactical manner. - No bunny hopping (why, god why) [edit: to be clear it was in Doom 3 and to me is a staple of id games since jumping has been in there games that sadly has been abandoned]. Many I know won't be bothered by this. - Textures are not poor per se, but certainly could be better. - Upgrades can be a little on the boring side at times, more health, armor, ammo etc. There weapon upgrades are good fun though. - Every time you change from single player, to multiplayer to snapmap the game exits and reopens. I minor complaint but still a little annoying. - Ending is very anticlimatic with clear sequel bait, which given id's track record may never come as a direct follow up.   The Neatral: +/-: DOOM is fast, like really fasst and thus unsuprisingly this game simply doesn't play very well with a controller. This is to be expected but if you intend to play that way expect your experience to be lessened. This really is a fps where m+k is neaded to play as it seems the designers intended. +/-: There may if anything be to large an emphasis on having color in every frame present. It isn't horrible but some darker areas would have been aprreciated. I imagine this is doubly so for massive doom 3 fans. +/-: There are many hoarde like moments where your basically put in an arena against swarms of enemies. I loved this especially because of the degree of verticality present. But I can see some disliking it.   From the multiplayer i've played, I suspect it may only have TDM be active like so many rescent pc shotters sadly.  Review to be updated as I play more.

DOOM is a first-person shooter about killing demons, demons, and more demons… and try to save humanity I guess. Much like the original Doom games, not even 5 seconds in and you’re already shooting! There’s no cover system, it’s all about running around like a maniac killing everything in sight. This is what Doom 3 should've been.  + Executions (“Glory Kills”) with over 30 different animations; similiar to brutal doom. + Great level design with large, well designed levels that often freely allow for backtracking. + Tons of secrets with early weapon unlocks and other fun things. + Nostalgic easter eggs, As expected from ID/Bethesda. + Awesome soundtrack that sticks to the roots of the series; a mix of good old metal with electronic elements. + Great aesthetic and visual fidelity. Not quite Frostbyte-level, but still very very good. + Classic pickup-based health system; no automatic regen. + Good enemy variety; at least 15 varieties. + Great weapon variety. Returning classics + some new additions, with 2 mods and a set of upgrades for each (like Wolfenstein TNO). + Carry all of your weapons at once and quickly switch between them (sadly not in the multiplayer). + No weapon reloading. I pressed R anyway for the first 30 minutes out of habit. + Fast load times. + Suit upgrades as incentive to find all the secrets. + Great story for a Doom game; good ending too! + Runs smoothly at 60+ fps. Usually held a full 60 at ultra on my R9 380. + No bugs, no crashes. + Good ol’ power-ups (Quad Damage, Haste, Invicibility, etc). + 10-20 Hour Campaign. Largely depending on how much long you hint for secrets. + 13 Doom classic levels, filled instead with the new weapons and monsters.  - OpenGL, so Steam broadcasting doesn’t work. - No soundtrack is available to buy at the time of the review. - Not enough bosses, though the ones there are well done. - Functional, fast-paced Multiplayer that’s taken far too much inspiration from the likes of Call of Duty. The full game offers more variety than the beta as well as SnapMap for a touch of creativity, but the core problems and imbalances still stand. - The Season Pass is said to only expand upon the multiplayer; I’d have loved more single-player content.  A solid addition to the Doom-series and a worthy reboot of the classic titles.  I hope we see a DOOM II!

This is how you revamp a classic franchise.  All the gameplay features, enemies, weapons and atmosphere that made the classic so great are present here but updated to what you'd expect from a modern FPS. Besides, it has a few features that make it outstanding: - A proper multiplayer with many game modes. - A level editor to create and share levels. - Demon rooms / play as a demon (multiplayer). - Glory kills: spectacular killing animations you can perform on weakened enemies, it works so well I'm sure we'll see this feature in many future FPS.  The only downside I found is that they had planned a few DLC and a season pass worth $40 since day one, something that has become too common in recent AAA games unfortunately. You get a complete and good experience without DLCs though as they are focused on multiplayer.  All in all, I enjoyed it from start to end and had a lot of fun playing multiplayer too.
I had an erection for 6 hours...  • This is the perfect re-imagining of the original games • Plays fast, tons of gore • Performs great even on mid-specs • Gives erections for 6 hours straight

HOLY HELL THIS IS WHAT IVE BEEN WAITING FOR!!!  A++++ 10/10   Just two levels in on NIGHTMARE mode and my heart was pounding. Heard a thud and looked to see that the cross on my wall was suddenly upside down, looked back at the screen and a demon tore my head off. Thumbs way up on this one.   Edit: I felt I should add a little more of why this game is so great. Concerning CAmpaign / Single player mode.   The graphics are just gorgeous and with my 970 on HIgh everything looks absolutely stunning. The music and ambience is perfect.  THe action is non stop (especially on NIGHTMARE) and everything is so badass. There are so many ways to kill and it just doesnt get old.  The enemies and AI is superb. I've only played on NIGHTMARE and if you arent constantly moving you're dead very quick. I can only imagine ultra nightmare.   The ONLY thing I dont like is that you cant save at will. Its all checkpoint based.   IVe been playing FPS games ever since Wolfenstein 3D and this is one of my favorites to date. Amazing job by the developres. They earned this $60 and it was entirely worth it. BUY IT NOW!
No aiming, no reload, almost no fall death and NPCs attack each other. Just like the old DOOM. Loved it!

Pretty much one of the or the best FPS I've played so far.  Smooth and fast paced gameplay, some nice background lore to discover what did you expect?  It's ♥♥♥♥ing DOOM! After a litany of bad unpolished unoriginal games and terrible PC ports, It's fair to say DOOM rises above all the recent PC games' failures.  DOOM is a polished game that is fun, smooth, and original because it is so different from modern shooters. Have fun tearing monsters to pieces without worrying about the ethics of simulated murder because they are demons that would happily kill everyone in their sight!  Single player has a robust upgrade system that constantly gives you new toys to play with. There are challenges in the SP that incentivizes mixing your attacks up. Also, there are great rewards for exploration as well! In DOOM, there is also an automap that is clean, slick, and accessible. When I first saw the automap in one of the gameplay trailers, I knew this game was going to be polished.  Multiplayer is great fun in general. Demon runes and power weapons strike fear into your enemies' heart, you will see them cower in fear as baron of hell charges head first into a fight. Snapmap is a great map tool, you can see that the developers spent time and effort finished the game before relaasing it.  Again, everything is completely polished and well made. I never felt i missed shots because of lag in multiplayer. I have not found a single glitch in single player. Great boss fights and when played on higher difficulty, it has a sort of dark souls feel to it, even though its supposed to be a FPS!  Seriously, i can't undestand why IGN has given this a 7.1. Its simply objectively wrong when you look at what other crappy unpolished unoriginal games you can get for the same price. I have not played a more fun FPS for a long time. I felt my money was well spent on a great product. With an upgrade system, DOOM SP cannot be said to be repetitive because of the variety of attacks and tactical decision you can make in a fight. Multiplayer can be played well after the SP has ended, so the game simply has much more replayability than many SP only games we have today. In DOOM, you can go head to head with a demon horde. There are simply not any game that I can really relate to, DOOM can really stand on its own!
What can I say...I am surprised!  I was expecting this to be another game where they try to remake the atmosphere of a previous game and completely fail at it. Instead, this game is awesome!   Pros:

PROS: It's frikking DOOM!  No longer taking the survival horror approach that DOOM 3 took, it's come back to it's roots with an awesome spin on its combat system and beautiful graphics.  CONS: NO......FRIKKIN...... CO-OP!!!! This was a huge blow for me, whose very first PC CO-OP game was the original DOOM. AOL, 33.8k Baud modem, Mom yelling at me that I was tying up the phone line. All to play a low res game with a good friend (R.I.P.), but I enjoyed every minute of it.  Even still, I recommend this game without hesitation.

If you have not yet bought this game, well, you should. 35 USD and even less on a Steam Sale. If you bough No Mans Sky for 60 USD, and not this for 35, you have serious mental problems.  GAME OF THE YEAR GUARANTEED.
Singleplayer Review

Single player is fantastic, playing on the hardest mode available for the initial campaign. Graphics and sound are spot on, combat is fast paced like the original series. No fluffy story, no endless cutscenes. Worth a buy.

The gameplay, animation, and wealth of content are incredible.   A perfect celebration and love letter to the originals, while being its own entry in the series.  The campaign, which I already expected to rock, blew me away with its presentation so far and I've barely gotten past level 3- there's a good reason for that.  Beyond the few hours I put into Deathmatch, which I'd already enjoyed in the closed and open betas, let alone the Alpha I was lucky enough to participate back in October... There's something beyond being the most solid FPS and incredible bar raiser in terms of single and multiplayer.   [SNAP MAP] Snap Map is what I expected- Little Big Planet: Doom.... But even more insane than that.  I never planned on spoiling (FOR MYSELF) admittedly little things, such as encountering monsters via Snap-Map I haven't yet faced in the campaign. Little stuff like that I'm OCD about. I want the fanfare, the setup and introduction of the enemy I know they'll recieve.... But holy ♥♥♥♥. It was worth it. Spent countless hours iterating on my own campaign with custom use of the incredible tracks provided in the game. (Mick Gordon is a ♥♥♥♥ing boss) .... Incredible design. It's every bit an SDK, Garrys Mod, and more. If you're smart with logic, boolean values and modifiers, use of and-if etc etc etc.... You can make pretty much whatever the hell you want- with the most iconic setting, arrangement of guns, and enemies ever. Be happy that Doom did this kind of content before some generic man-shooter. You can legit make your own experiences or simply play others in a streamlined way that makes this game STUPID in terms of value. Stupid in a ♥♥♥♥ing good way.   [MULTIPLAYER] The multiplayer is actually great. Everyone was whining and crying about it expecting a Quake game. Doom has never been Quake. Its multiplayer was very simplistic and open to interpretation. This Dooms multiplayer is an arena shooter with great pacing. Slower than crazy Quake players expect, but still much faster than most modern 'fps' fans can handle. I think it's a great inbetween with modern FEATURES that are not a detriment to the franchise. Doom is allowed to do whatever it damn well pleases when it comes to its multiplayer. It wasn't the first, but it coalesced the genre and is the ♥♥♥♥ing king. That said- loadouts and all of that really aren't a bad thing- it evens the playing field. If you're bad at the game that doesn't mean the game is bad. You are. The ONLY issue I have with multiplayer is matchmaking. Give me the ability to host a damn server. It'd help organize the community if we got a server list and the ability to host our own. And it'd mitigate some latency issues.   [UPDATE AFTER FINISHING CAMPAIGN]  Really there isn't much to add here. I don't want to ruin the campaign for anyone. It is glorious. It is perfection and plays so smoothly you'll honestly ask if she's legal.  [FINAL THOUGHTS] -The campaign is worth the price on its own. -The soundtrack is flawless. Only issue I have with it is I want more. -The multiplayer is fine. Get good. I just wish it had a serverlist. -Snap Map is awesome- It has a place in this game but I really wish there was better integration into the 'main' game... Not some side thing you have to load seperately. It isolates the content and doesn't get people to move over to it and breathe life into it very well. But the content I've played... (Gary Buseys Cocaine Adventure, awesome survival modes, a rogue-like 'farming' and dungeon exploring adventure....and honestly making my own maps and playing friends crazy creations) is amazing.    TL;DR- It doesn't just make a fan of the game that grew up with it, like me, lose their mind over the top perfect fan-service. Great references to the old entries in the series as well as an overall pitch perfect modernized feel to them... It sets itself far above the rest by being a solid game in its own right.  And then there' mother-♥♥♥♥ing Snap Map. Good luck putting it down.

DOOM is pretty cool, I guess.  Developed by Id software in 1993, DOOM was a revolutionary game that changed the way PC games would be made for the coming ye- What? There's a new one!? What year is it?  DOOM (2016) is pretty cool, I guess. You play as the Doom Guy, a very angry man who, much like me, battles with demons in strange and horrifying landscapes to stop a demonic invasion of Mars' moon of Phobos and the eventual invasion of Earth. The only difference is that Doom Guy's demons are very real and my demon is crippling drug abuse.   The interesting thing about the new Doom is that it really isn't a reboot per say, but kind of like a sequel to the events that happened at the end of DOOM 64, (By the way, someone ported DOOM 64 to the PC not too long ago, go check it out, it's kind of rad.)   Doom Guy was captured and placed in a sarcophagus by his enemies, but after being retrieved by a team of UAC soldier's led by Samuel Hayden, and a second demonic invasion occurs, Doom Guy is released from his slumber to once again rip and tear. Rip and Tear. Like the Doom comic. See, I'm hip. I know things.  What transpires is a 6 to 10 hour gauntlet of murder as the Doom Guy shoots, punches, chainsaws, cooks, cleans, files taxes, and goes on cute demon dates through the UAC facility that has been over run by...60,000 some demons, I think that was the number. But the story isn't important, even Doom Guy thinks the story isn't important, he just wants to show the imps and hell barons what the inside of their heads look like. I can respect that. So lets get to the good bits.  To say it simply and like a 3rd grader. DOOM is a love letter. Not just to DOOM, but the idea of DOOM and the idea of old-school shooters in general. You don't have to reload, you run surprisingly fast, you can carry all of the weapons at once, you can find power ups, and there are secrets on every level. It doesn't just feel like DOOM, but it almost also feels like QUAKE or even other games like Blood or Daikatana.  I made that last part up. I fooled you.   The levels are wide and open and beg for you to explore to find all of their secrets and easter eggs. Each level has a set amounts of secret collectibles and rooms to find, and you're rewarded for finding them. Sometimes you get stacked up on weapons and ammo, sometimes you get max health, and sometimes you get a little toy to put up on your wall along with your anime figures you ♥♥♥♥ing nerd.   At first, I didn't like the shooting, it felt slow to me and lacked impact. But it grew on me as the game went on and they added more and more weapons to your arsenal. It's like getting one of those budget games for the PS1 back in the day and then realizing that it's actually super good later on. That or finding a burrito with only one bite in it in the trash.  Who only bites once into a burrito? A communist, that's who.  I don't know why, but I think it was just the standard shotgun for me that turned me off at first. But the other weapons all have this amazing “Oomph” every time you pull the trigger. Everything from the assault rifle to the rocket launcher look, sound, and feel like they painful. Which makes sense because they're guns.  The weapons don't only blow off limbs, but tear away at flesh and splatter the room with chunky bits you could probably make delicious soup with. It's this crunch behind the guns that a lot of shooters seem to lack, giving them weight and feel to them.  Though I don't know why Doom guy even uses guns, considering the amount of damage he can do with his hands. The guy should look into boxing because he punches like three dump trucks going down hill at the same time.   When you do enough damage to an enemy, you have the option of finishing them off with melee while they're stunned. No, it's not just a little Halo rifle butt or a knife from Call of Duty, get that preschool ♥♥♥♥ out of here. No, instead Doom Guy will dispose of the critter in a plethora of brutal ways from tearing off jaws, ripping off limbs, beating them to death with their own arms, or just flat out punching through their head. It's a nice change in brutality that, at least myself, am use to seeing in modern video games.  And if all else fails you can just go the lumberjack route and slice them to bits with a chainsaw. Groovy.  I will now talk about the multiplayer.     I am done talking about the multiplayer.   Should you play ROOM: The moving in?   If I have any actual complaints about Doom is that it kind of drags on near the end, and as weird as this sounds, maybe it could be a little bit more Brutal? I don't know, I just feel like there could be a bit more blood and gibs flying around, make it something soccer mom's take notice to again. Lets get back to 1999 boys, someone call of Jack Thompson, we old school controversy now.   Other than that, DOOM is a pretty intense experience. It's kind of slow at first as it gets you into the swing of things, but if you stick with it, you're in for one of the most refreshing games in a long time.   DOOM gets 4 comic book references out of a possible 3.   Gary Busey eats people's teeth to gain power.   The curator:  http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

YES, YES, YES - i give DOOM 100 out of 10! jesus christ, i was hoping for something like this for such a long time - a linear Shooter  damn you: open world games damn you: stupid puzzle game...thing...whatever damn you: survival and exploration stuff  I just wanted a game...where i can blast em all away and don't have to worry about what to do next, where to go next or whatever.  finally i got it, just like in the old days perfectly right for a such a simple mind like me ;)

Absolutely worth the money.  Played only the Campaign so far, but after finishing it, i can say - this is DOOM. not slightly faster paced randomfps #1154 . Its graphics are good, music is awesome, and fast paced combat is exactly what was missing on the marked.  The mechanics around Glory Kills and Chainsaw force you to play more agressively and as time goes, u get used to them and start to like them. Weapon upgrades somehow fit the formula and are lots of fun (i really enjoyed the missile mod on Assault rifle :P ) . As a veteran who played doom 1 & 2 when they were originally released, i can say... Welcome back to Hell :)

As an old-timer (47), I've played all the 'old' FPS of the 90's and later iterations. Doom has succeeded in bringing back the feel of Quake and the other great ones. Good game design and level design, satisfying combat, just right difficulty on normal, good soundtrack and sound effects...most everything done right and very little to complain about.   It's been a long time since I rage-quite after repeadedly dying boss battles, but I kept coming back and victory was satisfying. Doom goes near the head of the class in the realm of FPS; I tip my hat to the development team.

You know you’re getting old when companies try to resell the pop culture of your youth to a new generation. With all the reimaginings, reboots and sequels to stuff two decades old going on lately, you’d have to be a zen master to not experience a certain sense of weariness kicking in. It doesn’t help that those warmed up retellings tend to be utter crap.  The original  Doom  is the OG of first person shooters. While it wasn’t the first FPS to ever be developed, it certainly was the most influential one, popularizing both the genre and PC as a platform for games. Kids all over the world craved it like it was digital crack. Offices had to ban  Doom  because it decreased the productivity of the employees drastically. University networks were crippled under the sheer load of people downloading and playing the game. If you were young in the early ‘90s, you had heard of  Doom . There was no way around it. And that was long before video games became as popular and common as they are now. Practically overnight,  Doom  made its creators millionaires.  The creators calling themselves id Software, those were just a handful of nerds fueled by their love for video games and heavy metal, both of which were reflected in their game. In  Doom , the player rushed through sci-fi inspired, maze-like levels filled with hellish imagery while gunning down demons left and right. But not only your reflexes were tested: Secrets were sprinkled all over the levels. The game encouraged exploration in order to have an edge over the satanic spawn. Often it was flat-out necessary to advance since the keycards unlocking specific doors were hidden quite well. It was fast, it was gory and it was quite the looker - 3D graphics were still a novelty and Doom achieved visuals never seen before while still being relatively easy on the hardware. In a way, it started the arms race of each new game trying to one up the last one in terms of graphics that lasts to this very day.   Doom ’s pop cultural impact was so huge, so undeniable, that the mere idea of a reimagining must seem like blasphemy. Much has changed since the early ‘90s. While  Doom  defined an entire genre in 1993, it’s just one of many first person shooters now. Other titles such as  Call of Duty  or  Halo  are considered the genre standard nowadays. The industry expanded, genre conventions changed a lot and so did the audience - not for the better, some would say. Storytelling is important now and a run and gun shooter like  Doom  may seem archaic in comparison. Plus, id Software is id Software in name only since none of the founding members are still working at the company. When the new  Doom  was announced, it had all the telltale signs of a cynical cash grab meant to sell by legacy only. Fans were worried that their holy cow would be turned into yet another generic first person shooter aping the conventions of other titles. But somehow, id Software pulled it off. They managed to do the original's roots justice.  Just so we’re clear here: id Software had some pretty big shoes to fill. So big, in fact, that nobody in his right mind could possibly expect them to make another game as revolutionary as the original  Doom . The goal rather seemed to be to introduce the frantic playstyle of classic first person shooters to a new crowd possibly unfamiliar with the original. The speed, the gore, the key hunting - it’s all there. If you grew up playing FPS games in the ‘90s you will feel right at home since the progression is almost identical: You get dropped in a new area, blast every demon in sight into bloody chunks while gracefully dodging projectiles and avoiding melee attacks. Once the last demon has been slain, it’s time to search the area for ammo, health packs and everything else that might give you an edge in upcoming confrontations, or unlock that one door that’s keeping you from advancing. The levels are surprisingly layered due to a high amount of verticality - even if you use the automap frequently, chances are you will miss many secrets regardless. Then you run into the next demon horde and the cycle repeats itself. New are the designated arenas that will shower you with enemies at the push of a button, allowing for some careful planning that is pretty much mandatory at higher difficulties.  What’s in here is just as important as what’s not. There is no regenerating health, no iron sights, no limitation regarding how many weapons you can carry and no excessive amount of cutscenes. The new  Doom  drops you into the action and pretty much leaves you there for the entire duration of the game. However, the world has kept turning since 1993 and some adjustments are to be expected. For instance,  Doom  has canned instakill animations performed on stunned enemies that drop ammo and health packs, depending on how urgent you need them. And like every action game these days, it features upgrade mechanics. Most of them influence the weapons’ secondary firing modes, but some work like the bandolier pick ups from the  Quake  series and increase the maximum amount of health or ammo you can carry. This alone may be enough to scare off purists.  Legitimately underwhelming is the art department, be it enemies or levels. It’s by no means bad, just unremarkable. And for a game dealing with depictions of hell, the new  Doom  is surprisingly tame - not so much in terms of gore and more regarding disturbing imagery. Even the oh so scolded  Doom 3  had twitching, vivisected men hanging from the ceiling. You will find nothing along those lines here. Also, I like to think that music played a part in the original’s success. It set the pace and pumped you up while you blew holes into the minions of hell. The new game’s industrial soundtrack is loud first and foremost and features many throwbacks to the iconic themes, but more often than not it sounds like it was created by discount Trent Reznor and loses itself in trivial creaking that doesn’t go anywhere. Additionally, the multiplayer is straight up deadweight.  So frag it like it’s ‘93? Not quite, but for the vast majority of it.  Doom  is definitely worth a look, whether you’re starved for a classic first person shooter or not. Apart from a few modern elements, it’s a rather accurate replication of that experience. It won’t leave a mark like the original did and it probably won’t revive oldschool twitch shooters, but it’s a fine game. Double so when taking into account how much worse it could have been.

I regard this new DOOM as a faithful return to the original franchise. Obviously it’s not going to be exactly the same, as the original game is far from perfect. With a lot of reboot franchises, the core of the game is usually lost, but this isn’t the case with DOOM.   Id Software have really poured their heart and soul into making this reboot as amazing as it could be, and then some. It reminds me of the original games, yet introduces new and interesting gameplay features that keep it up to date with modern games. It’s a perfect blend of old school meets new school. The new Id Tech 6 engine is one of the most impressive engines I’ve seen. Both in terms of graphics and performance. Granted my PC is above the recommended specs, but I’ve heard it performs well on a variety of systems. The performance was “unchained” essentially, and my computer could be fully utilized to give the best experience possible. Id clearly haven’t forgotten their roots.  The shooting is enjoyable and punchy. Each gun has 2 distinctly different weapon mods to unlock, which add a decent amount of variety to the combat. 2 weapon mods per gun doesn’t seem like much, but they change the way a weapon behaves in such drastic ways. Each stand out on their own, and by the end of the game I had unlocked all of them, and felt comfortable no matter which I was using.   Glory kills are another new gameplay feature. Fast and fluid melee executions that add serious variety to traditional fps gameplay. Originally I thought these would slow down the pace of the combat, but I can safely say I was wrong. They add brutality and enjoyment to an already brutal and enjoyable game :P  The multiplayer is satisfying to an extent. At first glance people assume it was a tack on, but looking into it further you can tell Id have really put some effort into this area. The amount of customization is insane. From acquiring different armour types, to changing the material and colours of your weapons. The gameplay is pure old-school Quake III, slightly slowed down and missing a few features though. Definitely worth your time if you have any interest in faster paced multiplayer.   The integrated SnapMap tool (used for building your own levels and sharing with others), offers a lot more on top of the single player and multiplayer, but sadly the limitations are far too obvious. Clearly it was a tool built with consoles in mind, hence the limited objects, and options. You can only have 10 demons spawned at once, and the building space is far too small. I really wish they would have removed these limitations on the PC version, but sadly I don’t see it happening any time soon. Still, SnapMap is a fun extra, to an already great game.  Buy DOOM, it’s worth every penny.

I'm quite the timid person in real life. I go to work every day, drink coffee, occasionally watch videos on youtube and all that. DOOM might not be exactly like it's old predesecor, but it's perfect for what it's trying to be. The high-octane violence with extreme maneuverability and over-the-top demonic theme set it aside from any recent FPS on the market. No crouching behind chest-high walls, stealth sections or escort missions. Just you, an objective and legions of demons in between.   PROS: +Exactly what is says on the tin +A plethora of weapons, upgrades and challenges to keep the carnage fun +Amazing soundtrack and overall thematic feel +Varying level design with impressive scenery and with increasing difficulty. +Hideously-awesome monsters and bosses that you can study in detail with their logs and unlockable models. +The combat system is fantastically balanced. Example: going in close and using a chainsaw to earn ammo for your empty guns isn't 'realistic', but it IS engaging and fun as hell. +The game is self-aware and doesn't take itself to seriously. There's even some humour in small amounts. +Change difficulty and controller style to what feels best for you.  CONS: -The rather predictable story might not be your cup of tea at all. I found it pretty cool myself though. And funny at times if you don't take it very seriously. -Backtracking, looking where you need to go and finding secrets in the confusing maps can sidetrack you too long from the action, but YMMV. -If you ignore all the secrets, challenges and extra's then the core game is only about 5-7 hours long depending on your skill. -Replay value is pretty low unless you're looking for bigger challenges.I do hope to see more variation in enemies and how you engage them in future installments. -Multiplayer is quite extensive in customisation and game-modes but wasn't engaging enough for me to keep playing or buy the OVERPRICED DLC.  I for one can't wait for the sequel and see more cool demons and crazy levels!

I literally never write reviews for anything, but considering that Doom is perhaps my new all-time favorite FPS campaign, I felt I owed it to the developers and community to share my honest opinions. Doom, simply-put, is absolutely incredible. This game has greatly exceeded the somewhat high expectations I had set for it after watching a solid amount of footage before release. The visuals are absolutely stunning and the game runs very well on my 7/10 PC at max settings.   You're thrown into action almost immediately, the basic and near-perfect gameplay formula shining right from the start. The fluidity of the movement, the fast-paced, feel-like-a-badass combat, and the perfect execution of weapon indroduction, upgrade pace and variety. It's as the developers said, the game is a frantic chess board, of sorts, in which your enemies take their spots and you quickly formulate, execute and constantly re-evaluate your approach to every battle, as it progresses. When you become comfortable with all the pieces the game offers you as you play through it, every battle almost feels like a dance. Constant weapon swapping, leaping from platform to platform, never stopping to breath until the music slows down. It just feels so damn natural and perfect.  Halo 1 was the first time I played a FPS and thought, 'this formula is just so perfect that I could play the game over and over again and never get tired of it'(which I did). Well, I'm here to say that Doom is as close to formula perfection as I've seen since the first Halo. That's not to say that the two games are similar in how they play, just that each design element has been so perfectly-crafted and results in such incredible synergy that something special is born as a result. Doom is special, there is no doubt about that.  I've played countless FPS games over the years and I'm confident in admitting that Doom is the most fresh and most fun FPS of this generation. This game is going places, and I couldn't be happier.  Pros: -Incredible visuals, both technical and artistic -VERY well-optimized, I'd estimate about 60fps average throughout most of the game at max settings -Near-perfect gameplay formula, resulting in a foundation that could support an endless amount of content -Frantic, gorey, visceral combat that NEVER gets old and plays out differently each time -Excellent weapon and gear upgrade systems that encourage you to explore the gorgeous maps for secrets -Fantastic arsenal, a gun for every situation. Even at the end of the game I found myself constantly swapping between 5-6 guns, not including the mods being swapped on each gun, which can drastically change the way they function. -Surprisingly-long campaign with excellent pacing and environmental variety, considering the source material -Dialogue is very well-delivered and never induces cringe or slows down the pace of the game to undesireable levels  Cons: -Player and monster-created light sources don't cast shadows. This is a pet peve of mine when it comes to games with amazing lighting systems. I understand the implications on performance to have all those light sources casting shadows on nearby geometry, but the immersion factor gained from implimenting this type of visual effect is significant and often jaw-dropping. It's very rare to find this in games, and Doom should absolutely not be without it -2 or 3 poorly optimized areas, resulting in strange framerate drops. -Would have liked a 4th rune slot and the ability to further level up the power of my guns through more in-game challenges. The guns are fantastic, but at some point the earlier weapons are mostly phased out unless you run out of ammo. -Certain weapons have their sensitivity changed either while firing or while zooming in/charging weapon mod fire. This can be VERY hurtful during combat. There need to be individual sensitivity options for these weapons/mods. -The game ends

Rarely do we get to see a AAA title where every aspect of the game in centered around one single element, in this case, combat. Art direction, sound design, story, movement, level design... everything here is built to create the best FPS experience possible, and DOOM delivers. This is definitely one of the best FPS campaigns in recent years.
