Rise of The Tomb Raider by Crystal Dynamics Score 9 / 10 (Solid)   Great news for Lara fans; the PC version of “Rise of the Tomb Raider” delivers a grandiose noggin scratching ancient history conspiracy theory driven plot pitting the multi-generational Croftian zealotry for ‘divine artifacts’ versus the archetypal villains with too much money, power, and religiosity; ‘follie-a-trois’ n’est-ce pas? More importantly, does this game have puzzles?  Present and expected are the improbably improbable puzzles ubiquitous to the Lara universe; I ‘pray’ for these contraptions with secrets hidden beneath massive moveable walls and oversized cogs each controlled through a series of timed switches powered by gravity and water. A little bit of patience always yields a Codex with life changing knowledge (nudge-nudge wink-wink). Inexplicably these puzzles seem to have been relegated to the “optional side missions”, a direct in-game quote. These are the classic Tomb Raider pieces that I love and I completed them as soon as possible; they always yielded extra XP, gold coins and skills; I wish these puzzling sections had been way longer. What then is ‘central’ to this digital archeological hunt? Read on….  The main plot unfolds wrapped as a “third person shooter”. Feeling a bit shaky are you? Yep, the spelunking has really taken a back seat to the shooter gameplay. There should have been far more dialogue options for negotiations, skillful stealth mode with zero death, and more creative gameplay in the central campaign. Has Crystal Dynamics made a choice or a mistake? Don’t get me wrong, I love shooters but not this one. Combat with guns in tight spaces and an over the shoulder camera leads to a poor combat experience. Would you like a game with great combat, weapons and well designed arenas? Try Unreal Tournament 3 Black edition instead. Consequently, I found myself avoiding all main story paths as long as possible because they were so combat unpleasant, and eventually I set the game to the easiest setting to make these encounters as short as possible. What else made the campaign a grind? The controls are ‘tuned’ for parkour platforming; mid combat my character kept putting away the gun and jumping into water or grabbing a ledge; who wants fudge? The default graphics settings use over-the-top screen effects making it uncomfortable: ‘water splashes on the lens’, ‘depth of field’, and others, all of them summing to a ‘digital finger in the eye’. Thank you Crystal Dynamics for letting me turn off all those ‘enhancements’ in the options menu.   Crafting and skill trees were welcome and enjoyable although heavily dependent on hunting. The upgrade mechanics lead to a veritable slaughter-fest: I must have killed over 700 bunny rabbits, 300 deer, 50 wild boars, 10 grizzly bears, and a partridge in a pear tree. In fact I started farming previous maps for humans because they had the specialized parts. The weapon upgrades yielded for the most part palpable advantages in engagements: Would anyone like an RPG arrow head? Woooooo! The remaining XP system felt hollow and served to redirect you back to previous maps, that is, if you want to find all coin stashes, hidden provisions, caves and relics. Meh. This is just a poor substitute for replayability.  Crystal Dynamics have done superbly well with the extra game modes. I was particularly impressed with “Endurance” mode placing Lara in the Siberian wilderness to see how many days you can survive; requirements to eat, stay warm, collect resources, craft, and collect artifacts improve your chance of survival and reward the players having skill. Many players will enjoy “Score Attack” mode, an arcade version of the campaign. “Replay” game mode allows you to compare yourself to your Steam buddies through point accumulation.   What else should you look forward too? A visually stunning and sprawling game world. check. Tons of Steam Achievements. check. One Special achievement for teaching BBQ chicken to fly. Sweet! Puzzle deaths: 30 times in a row with a game reload. Blame wonky controls. Rage quit. double check. ‘Collision detection’ that doesn’t know ‘collision’ from a ‘hole in the wall’. triple check. Excessive grunts, breathing, and expletives in that sublime British accent. Yeah.  Buy this game; all Tomb Raider fans will find something they were looking for and ‘more’. Thumbs up.    My score 9 / 10  10 / exemplary execution of the genre with compelling innovation  9 / exemplary execution of the genre don’t miss out, for fans of the genre and the curious alike  8 / for well done not a must play, fans of the genre and newbs will be happy it is well done  7 / for calibrated expectations only, fans of the genre would not miss out if they skipped this 6 / only for serious fans of the genre for whom game play with bugs is acceptable 5 / enough bugs to make me unhappy  2016.02.17
Originally posted by  Raymond :
I cannot help to call this reboot of Tomb Raider in 2013 nothing but remarkable.     Do not get confused with my playtime, I already have played this game on Xbox one.      Rise of the graphics:

Just finished Rise of the Tomb Raider. If you want to go in as a clean sheet, you might get  spoilered  FYI.  + fewer control loss of player character for repetitive animations/transitions + sprinting exists + sublime visuals + animations are much better + visual variation much, much better + story much more interesting + characters are a vast improvement + VO overall much better + bigger tombs with unique flair to them, pay-off is worth it this time (special skills) + hunting big game is fun + enjoyable and fitting additions to Lara's moveset + deeper crafting system and thus expanded resource system + special ammo and throwable can be crafted on the go which spices up otherwise mundane combat system + stealth is serviceable + longer, meatier game  - inconsistent performance - map bugs out frequently - many useless skills - despite giving hope at the start, not a globetrotting adventure - platforming is way too linear, no chance of doing something wrong, it's a one-way street - free-form jumping, somersaulting needs to come back for the good of platforming sections - combat lacks fun, melee plain sucks - acquiring new weapons is tedious and takes too long - weapon variety is not enough, where is my sniper, rocket launcher, exotic weapon? the ones present are too 'safe' - story progression feels too similar to prequel - many useless collectibles which are not fun to waste hours on - prehistoric audio-log mechanic makes them a chore to listen  Maybe it's TR13 disappointing me so much and me having little to no expectations for this but I had significantly more fun with RotTR. Story wrapped up faster than I liked just when I finally reached the MacGuffin but it was still OK. I don't like that Trinity is apparently becoming the overarching enemy from now on in the reboot though. There's a lot of combat, just like in the prequel but the new crafting-on-the-go with the nice selection of alt-ammo for every weapon made it better. There's still a lot I want them to change, add and improve for the sequels. Combat is still nothing noteworthy and that is pretty bad when you have so much of it. Same goes for platforming. It's a glorified QTE system. Expand on the jumping system, design the levels so that I can jump, hang and land everywhere and have to figure out the way on my own, not this linear solution. It's not satisfying. Overall, it's a better game which improved a lot of my initial complaints but not extensively enough. I had fun, it's OK.

Pros:    Lengthy Campaign   Top notch Graphics   Fun Exploration   Great Environments   CGI-like Cutscenes   Expedition Mode   Lara is even moar hotter :'3   Runs well for a Next-Gen Game   Cons:    Cliché story   AI is dumb af   Microtransactions   Tons of Collectibles   Feels repetitive sometimes   Anti-Aliasing solutions are a joke (even SSAA)   Have to equip only any 5 challenges in an Endurance Mode    DONOT use speakers or people will think that you are watching porn  9/10

Rise of the Tomb Raider is the one of the best action adventure game I played.   Pros:-   Open world is massive and timming with life. There is sense of an adventure in every corner of the world.   Survial element is fun part of the game. You need to craft weapons and items to survive the wilderness. There are lots of predators that you need to look out for like bears, wolfs, leopards and cugars. Predators are hard to take down so you need to play tactically.   There are lots of differnt way you can approach a situation when you encounter enemies. This makes the game fun. Stealth is very good in this game compare to Tomb Raider 2013. AI is smart, when they discover the dead body they alert the other guys and search for you.   Environment sounds are great and Great voice acting by Camilla Luddington.   Lots of weapons and gears to choose from. You can be a rambo with bow and arrows. There are different type of arrows to choose from like fire, poison and explosive arrows.   Graphics is so awesome. This is the best looking game I played in my life.   Character animations and Facial Expressions are so life like that it is feel like you are watching a movie.   Side missions and Optional tombs are very good. There are lots of optional challange tombs in the game that make this game a true tomb raider experience. Puzzles in the tombs are very well balanced. They are not so hard but not so easy too.    Challanges and collectibles give this game some replaybility.   Lots of achivements. More achivements allows you to experience the game in different ways if you like to 100%.   Story is very good. There are documents to find that allows you to dive in to the lore of the game further.   DLCs are great. You can modify the experience of DLCs using cards.   Optimization is great but to MAX it you need newer hardware.   Cons:-   Nothing I can find.   If you haven't played this game yet then you are missing a masterpiece. I give this game 10/10.

Rise of the Tomb Raider is an action adventure game developed by Crystal Dynamics and published by Square Enix. This game is the sequel to the 2013 release of Tomb Raider. Rise of the Tomb Raider was released initially on Xbox in November 2015, but has just been released in January 2016 for PC. It is also due to release on PS4 later in the year.   Fans of the series will probably know what to expect when it comes to Tomb Raider. The reboot in 2013 changed the formula to the original series, and Rise of the Tomb Raider continues with the reboot’s theme. You play as Lara Croft in a third person view and you have to battle through enemies and solve puzzles with a good amount of platforming involved too. Much like the previous game, there is also a crafting system, allowing you to create medi-packs, upgrades for your weapons, different ammunition along the way as you collect materials. What I wasn’t too keen on in the previous release was that a lot of the game play was focused on the “all guns blazing” aspect, whereas Rise gives you a lot more option to play stealthily. You can of course go with route one and go gung-ho, but if you want to sit back and plan your attacks meticulously without being spotted, you can do that too. The weaponry in the game is almost the same as the previous game too; with my favourite returning, Lara’s bow. There is now the addition of throwing items such as tin cans and Molotov’s at the enemies to either act as a distraction or just for damage. The platforming has had some interesting additions, such as being able to scramble up walls that are a little too high for Lara’s regular jump. This makes traversing the environments a little bit easier than normal.   I played Rise of the Tomb Raider on 4k, with all of the graphics turned up to max, and sweet baby Jesus this is one gorgeous looking release. The facial animations on every single character are finished to perfection. It is almost like you are sitting straight in front of Lara, so much detail and effort has gone into making everything look just gorgeous! I find myself saying this every couple of weeks, but the animation has seriously blown everything out of the water in my opinion. Not to mention the stellar voice acting throughout the game too, with Camilla Luddington returning to play Lara Croft.   I can’t say that Rise was a very difficult game to complete; there are a lot of puzzles to complete throughout the play through, but none of them are so hard I had to refer to a walkthrough. You simply have to study your surroundings for a second before taking any action. The combat scenes are probably the trickiest part of the game, especially in the later stages of the game when you are pretty much forced into using your bow against hordes of enemies instead of being able to rip them to shreds with your sub machine guns.   Throughout your play through of the game, you will find artefacts in abundance. These upgrade certain skills for Lara when finding them and you can even be rewarded with regular experience points if you choose that talent when you level up. They add a lot of extra plot and lore to the story with a lot of it revolving around a lot of the main characters. You will also find that there are hundreds of items to collect, whether it be scavenging for materials to make an upgrade for a weapon, or finding the collectables, you will never find a section of a level empty with nothing for you to want to explore and find. A new addition for Rise is side quests. Throughout the game you will find a handful of side missions that you can complete which will reward you with either a new weapon or piece of equipment to help you on your travels. Whilst you can complete the game without any of the rewards, they are simply there as an additional resource for skills and experience.   I finished my play through of Rise in just over 12 hours. Whilst this is still fairly short, it is certainly an improvement over the previous game which only took me about 7 hours to complete. There are a few additional game modes you can play when finishing the game. You can firstly go back and replay older chapters in order to finish collecting and finding items. You can replay the chapters but on an elite difficulty whilst also keeping all of your equipment and skills from your previous save though. Score attack, which means trying to complete a chapter as quickly as possible but with a new set of rules in place, such as chaining together different attacks. This means you can probably get about 20 hours of content out of the game, maybe more if you are really into it. There is a season pass available for the game which promises a couple things, such as extending the single player experience in the story, and will also add a multiplayer mode.   As I said above, I played the game on 4K with all my settings ramped up to max. I was able to play the game perfectly fine with 60 FPS. The game was installed on an SSD so loading times were almost none existent. I played the game with keyboard and mouse due to the need to be quite precise when it comes to aiming and jumping etc.   The latest release of from the Tomb Raider series really does it self-proud in my opinion. Whilst some may consider this game bad due to the poor sales figures it received when releasing, a lot of that was due to another extremely popular title being released on the same day. Now the game has come to the proper gaming platform, it is truly an experience everyone needs to take for themselves. The price of £35,99 on Steam is OK. I personally don’t ever tend to buy games for full price but this game was one that I actually pre-purchased just for my love of the series and I am more than happy with my purchase with this game. As we’ve seen with the last game in the series, it will go on sale fairly quickly, so you may want to wait a few months to get it for at least half off.      Tom's Score Card   1) Stay away 2) Not Recommended 3) Only recommended when on sale 4) Recommended 5) Highly recommended   6) This is a must play    If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking  here .

If you played the last tomb raider game, you will immediately feel right at home with Rise of the Tomb Raider. I say that as a positive thing, becuase Tomb Raider has really improved upon the gameplay elements, graphics and exploration.  So last game was sort of an experiment. It was a reborn of the series and it was a pretty nice, but casual and linear sort of game. This game is still very casual, just like the last game, but levels are more open, and there's things to find in every corner. I like that, becuase im the explorer type in this sort of games. I like exploring to learn more about the world, get upgrades and just get more out of the game.  The story is interesting and kept me playing. I remember that I liked the last tomb raider story as well. This is more of the same. Another journey, but with different landscape. The mountains filled with snow and ice looks great.  Game runs well, but it's really demanding with lots of settings. To play this on ultra you need a beast PC. I play with 980 SLI and because I play 1440p I had to crank some settings down to maintain over 60 fps. This game is filled with all kinds of graphics options, like hair physics, which is only something certain AAA-developers include in their title.  Voiceacting is good, and the sound effect are cool. There's some QTE's in this game, which I don't particulary like. Still, I think the last game had more of it, and most combat in this game is full of action and choice. You can stealth through or go guns blazing. You can also upgrade weapons and equipment more then last game and use that to make the combat more varied.  I honestly don't have any real complaints about this game. It's a good AAA-game with a lenghty story (I probably rush through large parts of it, and also played on an easy difficult mode), nice graphics, story, sound, controls, options menu. Levels are more open, crafing, weapons, etc, have more customization then the last Tomb Raider game.  The ending is very open and definitely sequel baiting. Don't get me wrong though, you get a complete story in this game, but at the same time it does hint at more. I would be okay with another game though. I enjoyed the first remaster of Tomb Raider, and I also enjoyed this title a great deal. Recommended.

DO NOT BUY ENDURANCE MODE. READ BELOW.  Rise of the Tomb Raider is better at everything Tomb Raider (2013) did, which was a pretty good game. Rise is as good of an action adventure game of this type I've played. If you're into these types of games, this is one of the best ones, plain and simple.   Some minor complaints are that it starts to narrow to an action oriented game only in the last couple of hours. Throughout the game there is a healthy medium between exploring and combat. The last couple of area's of the game look very cool but basically cannot be explored at all. First of all, there is nothing noteworthy to find in them and secondly you're 'forced' into combat constantly. It's not that the main game lets you avoid combat, but you can engage with it when you are ready for the most part. In the final hours it's all: 'nope, more combat, go!'  It makes sense narratively, but I'd rather they would've come up with a way for it to make sense to still explore and be stealthy if you choose.   The very final hours are combat overload and keep spawning guys against you. It's not the greatest, but unlike most other games, it doesn't feel ridiculous. You are plenty powerful at that point and even playing on the highest difficulty setting I had no problem disposing of everyone. And the combat is fun. So it was still a fun section, just not as good as the rest of the game.   Now as for DLC...  DO NOT ♥♥♥♥ING BUY ENDURANCE MODE. It is a shell of a game mode. Survival? Nope. Here's the thing, it has a Hunger Meter and a Warmth meter. Kind of like Don't Starve. Shoot one deer, loot it, whoop! Hunger is full again. No food preperation, no setting up camp, nothing. There is also no crafting or camp creation. It's just a bunch of fires spread around the map and you can light them for 5 wood. Clothing has zero influence on all of it. You can wear a tanktop if you want. Stand near the fire, it's full again.   All meaningless survival stats. Start the game up, 2 minutes in you have a bunch of wood for fires and you shot a couple deer. Congratiolations! You've beaten Endurance Mode!   Yeah... it's bad. There is nothing to do to actually make survival matter. I was expecting skinning bears for better clothing or having to craft camp fires and build a shelter. Nope, none of that.   Don't. Buy. Endurance. Mode.   It's a waste of 10 bucks.

Rise of the Tomb Raider is more of the same, only better.         YouTube™ Video:  Rise of the Tomb Raider (PC) - 60fps Gameplay & Review - A Sheepish Look At

Pros:  - The game now has some replay value with the expeditions and endurance mode, eventhough the rank ladder is already spoiled thanks to cheaters.  - Decent combat system, weapons with many different variants and addons.  - More complex puzzles compared to the 2013 version.  - Beautiful scenery, also the way that Lara's clothes get dirty as you interact with the enviroment is pretty cool.  - Good voice acting  - NPCs that gives you side missions and rewards.  - Good hunting system.  Cons:  - Performance issues, mainly on Soviet Installation and Geothermal Valley, FPS drops randomly doesn't matter how good your system are.  - Game takes your hand and walk you through everything, even on 'Survivor', this game difficult is a joke.  - Survivor Instincts + having the locations for everything on the map narrows the scope of the game, paving 'the 100% completed' way right in front of the player instead of making the player explore the world for himself.  - 90% of the puzzles are optional. If you rush through the path the game indicates, you can finish this game in a couple hours.  - Eventhough you are climbing and jumping over cliffs most of the time, it's really hard to fall, like, you must put a lot of effort to achieve such feat, because the game is dumbed down so much, that it refuses to let you die. If you step over a cliff Lara automatically grabs the edge and etc. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Overall a good game, I wish it was not so dumbed down, at least on the hardest difficulties it shouldn't be so fricking easy. But yet it is.  I hope they can fix the performance issues for now.

Time for money and optimization review.   Finally the game is optimized now that the lastest patches is in and Nividia drivers have updated. I went from high settings 30-50fps to Maxed out 77 average frames. GTX 1060 6 GB.   If you liked TR13 then you should put this game on your list to buy. The story is 13-30 hours long and is filled with the other 2 story based DLC that will easily take you over too 40hrs along.   Co-op, collectables and challenges this game has will add even more hours. I currently have 47hrs in, 60/100+ achievements, and 80% story completion and still have a lot to do.

Gameplay wise it's pretty much the same but a lot more collectibles and more challenge tombs.   Wait until October for the full collection and you'll get the game with all the DLC.

English and Portuguese reviews below. *English* In regards of graphical fidelity, it's the most advanced I've ever seen 'till todays day, most people would agree with that. Nothing comes even close, especially in 3D Vision, and the devs keeps adding more stuff like the new ambient occlusion called VXAO, that surpasses the already very good HBAO+, among other things. Gameplay is very enjoyable and it never gets boring, at least I didn't felt bored at any point while playing (some of my friends said it was so good that they rushed to the ending, and the game felt short due to this). Story is the usual hollywood cliche but that's not game breaking, it suits Lara Croft universe pretty well infact. The voiceover is very well done, like in the first of the franchise reboot (2013), and there is a brazilian voiceover option now that's above the standards.  PSA: The engine is a huge step up from the TR 2013, and it's also very GPU heavy, but it has so many options to mess with that even if you don't have a very powerfull highend PC, you still can enjoy the game with a relentless presentation. So there is no excuse to not play the game, unless you are the kind of PC player that buys a GPU at a given time and expects it to run all games at 60FPS maximum settings ad eternum, it's just silly. So don't expect to have top notch graphics with your GPU forever, 'cos that's not how it works. The engine is very flexible, so the player must to be flexible too. In other words: Don't be delusional.  I highly recommend this game for the ones that wants a very good single player gaming experience. Lara Croft has never looked so good.  *Portuguese*  Em relação de fidelidade gráfica, é o mais avançado que eu já vi até o dia de hoje, a maioria das pessoas concordaria com isso. Nada chega perto, especialmente em 3D Vision, e os devs continua a adicionar mais coisas como a nova técnica de oclusão de ambiente chamada VXAO, que ultrapassa o já muito bom HBAO+, dentre outras coisas. A jogabilidade é muito agradável e ela nunca fica chata, pelo menos eu não senti entediado em qualquer ponto durante a jogatina (alguns dos meus amigos disseram que era tão bom que eles rusharam para o final, e o jogo pareceu ser curto devido a isso). História é o habitual clichê de Hollywood, mas isso não estraga o jogo, ele combina com o universo Lara Croft muito bem na verdade. A dublagem é muito bem feita, como no reboot da franquia (TR 2013), e agora há uma opção de dublagem brasileira que é acima dos padrões.  PSA: O motor gráfico é um grande avanço baseado no mesmo motor do TR 2013, e também é muito pesado no lado da GPU, mas tem tantas opções para mexer nele que, mesmo se você não tem um PC high-end muito potente, você ainda pode desfrutar do jogo com uma apresentação implacável. Portanto, não há desculpa para não jogar o jogo, a menos que você seja do tipo de jogador de PC que compra uma GPU em um determinado momento e espera que ela seja capaz de executar todos os jogos em configurações máximas a 60FPS ad eternum, isso é bobagem. Portanto, não espere ter gráficos topo de linha com o sua GPU para sempre (como muitos infelizmente pensam), pois não é assim que a coisa funciona. O motor gráfico é muito flexível, de modo que o jogador deve ser flexível também. Em outras palavras: Não seja delirante.  Eu recomendo este jogo para aquele que quer uma experiência single player muito boa no gênero que o jogo se propôe. Lara Croft nunca esteve tão bem.

Tomb Raider is slowly but surely becoming one of my favorite game series.  I am fascinated by the fun, the beauty and the great story it tells.  Breathtaking visuals, fantastic music and sounds, The voice acting is great, it is so engaging, so immersive. A little Uncharted here and there, some Zelda even, I am about a third through and I cannot go slowly enough for fear of it ending too quickly, it is just too too good. I hope they keep making them and making them better. If you liked the previous Tomb Raider you will love this one, it is an improvement on every aspect. Smarter deeper tombs and puzzles, more RPG elements, nicer story bigger levels, fun missions. So much replayability. Just a fantastic title overall. Buy it now, it's worth every penny.

But it works. - A few of the plot twists i kinda saw coming, but the story is entertaining nonetheless.

Rise of the Tomb Raider takes a formula used for the original reboot and creates a much cleaner, polished game overall. For fans of the first one, expect a lot more of the same overall gameplay. For those who were wary or had some complaints about the first, ths second installment may have addressed some of those issues.  At the heart, it's still very much an action-adventure ala the Uncharted series. Many of the same mechanics seen in the first TR are still here: wall climbing, upgrades to weapons, stealth kills, etc. However, these systems go somewhat deeper, allowing for a more varied and advanced crafting system, as well as outfits. The various areas of exploration proivde a wealth of materials, and many of the fights have opportunities for multiple solutions, be it straight up brawls, using moltov cocktails, or stealthily moving about. QTE's are kept to a minimum and used mostly in obvious locations. The addition of the Marketplace and Expedition system also add a good deal of replay to the game that fell flat in the first game, unlocking new gear, outfits, and customized challenges to certain areas of the game.  As you explore and fight, the game also has a plethora of hidden areas, tombs, achievement items, and so on. The tombs are more robust this time around, and there seem to be many more of them to go through. While not overly difficult, most of them also provide direct upgrades to your talents and weapons, giving players motivation to solve them. Plus, they are created in beautifully rendered environments that fully immerse players in the game world.  If there are any drawbacks, those graphics are still a bit of an issue. I'm using a somewhat older system with an HD 7750. The game runs, for the most part, fine. The hair effects in particular do not give me the same problems the original did at first. However, there is still noticeable slowdown in areas with large amounts of water effects, as well as the start of most cutscenes, which is frustrating. It's a gorgeous game, to be sure, but without an option to adjust draw distance, it can be quite hefty for lower-end systems.  Overall, I'd say this is a similar step up to the ones the Batman series had after Arkam Asylum: a great game that takes most of the template of the first installment and expands upon it in a largely positive way. They clearly took a lot of the feedback of the first game to heart and did their best to make one of Lara's best games yet. It might not win fans who want strict reliance on the original 1990's games, but I'm having a blast.

Pretty good game for the most part. Pros: - Decent story, however it's not executed as well as it could have been. - The graphics are fantastic, really nice effects, Lara's hair looks awesome with purehair at very high. There's some nice scenic areas that are nearly as nice as witcher 3, nearly. - There are some nice semi-open areas which are really nice, it's not sandbox though. - The gameplay as far as tomb raiding is pretty good.  Cons: (Most of these are only a little annoying) - most of the combat scenes are very linear, with very restricted ways to approach enemies and this can get boring and frustrating when you want to be creative. The distraction techniques only work so well. - The combat areas are very scripted, often enemies coming from another room, with no possible way to see where Lara is, will know instantly where you are and immediately start firing exactly where you are. - The AI is both stupid and omnipotent at the same time e.g. I've taken down a whole room of soldiers standing near each other but slightly off from directly in front of each other, just with my bow, and none noticed their friends dropping like flies. Other times you can throw a molotov near an enemy and none of them were looking anywhere to see where you threw it from, but they instantly knew exactly where I was. - I've found times I've thrown a molotov, then hidden behind a wall, and all the while out of sight then moved to a different area and found the enemy to come straight to where I'm now hiding. - The combat mechanics are really clunky. you can't block, you can't go crouch or prone unless it's scripted for you too. When near enemies, Lara often stands bolt upright when she should be crouched, there's limited way to move between cover in any stealthy way. - The stealth mechanics are crap, I'm sorry, they just suck. - Enemies being able to see through thick smock to shoot accurately at Lara, despite not being able to see them on the other side, and no, they didn't have thermal vision goggles. - The camera often misbehaves, showing us what it thinks we want to look at. It would be nice to have more control over it, It also doesn't handle well when you move through a doorway whilst aiming a weapon, good luck seeing anyway but the wall. - Maybe I'm just picky, but the 'tomb raiding' is too easy and too scripted. - Want to jump over a knee high barricade? Nope, not allowed there, oh there's a spot you can crawl through, nope again. - The arrows are not realistic, in any way, physics just doesn't seem to apply to them.  Don't get me wrong, it's a fun game and I'm enjoying it for the most part, but I didn't have to think much to find all those little problems that seriously shouldn't exist in a game like this, and the sad thing is, the main problems are with gameplay, the game looks beautiful, but there's lots of gameplay issues that could have been addressed, this really feels like it was dumbed down from what it should have been, sad thing is, the dumbing down is probably deliberate.

If you liked 2013's Tomb Raider, you'll love this game. Rise of the Tomb Raider improves on its predecessor in almost every way, with better gameplay, better graphics, better sound design, better pacing and most importantly, more actual tombs to exploreI i was dazzled by the size and scope of the island, the fast paced cinematic 'escape' sequences, the simple yet captivating shooting mechanics and the boldness of delving so frankly into supernatural territory. Rise of the Tomb Raider just came out a few weeks ago here and I nabbed it as soon as I was able. It delivered everything I expected it would, a decent story with Lara's first encounter with Trinity and the race to find the 'Divine source', an object that grants those that gaze upon it immortality before it falls into Trinity's fanatical hands. The combat remains fun, fast paced and somewhat easier with less need to take cover and instead allowing the run and gun approach. The traversal is more detailed this time around, with Lara having more tools at her disposal which unlocks areas previously inaccessible to her, like the Rebreather, Broadhead climbing arrows, and the ability to throw her pickaxe as a grapple hook. The crafting system has been overhauled, with Lara being able to craft bigger ammo and resource storage pouches as well as innumerous upgrades for each variant of pistol, shotgun, machine gun and bow. Most of these upgrades requires special animal hides, which Lara can acquire by finding hidden caches or through good old fashioned hunting. Bears and feral felines make an appearance this time as potential hunts for rare skins, but they won't go down without one hell of a fight... Lara can craft special ammunition on the go and accept side quests from allies who reward her with otherwise unobtainable rewards like new gear or attire. The tombs this time are more numerous and a lot more complicated to solve, at least the first time around. Completing them rewards Lara with unique skills like faster climbing, triple arrow shots and the ability to mine for rare metals required for the best weapon upgrades. There are also crypts in which Lara may find weapon parts and coin caches she can dig up to trade for weapon attachments and unique weapons. Unlike the previous game, it is highly unlikely that you will be able to acquire every skill and upgrade before the end, unless of course you enjoy grinding the same groups of enemies for hours, and so skill and upgrade choices need to be selected more thoughtfully and resources spared for the weapons you enjoy using most. The areas Lara visits are not as numerous as the previous game, but they are unquestionably larger, some maps may take hours and hours to complete while the transition areas usually take about an hour. Not every NPC is hostile towards Lara and there is one particular area that is home to a village filled with friendlies who Lara must help defend against Trinity  Pros 1) The game looks and plays amazingly well. 2) Gameplay 3) Graphics 4) Sound design   Cons 1) Major FPS drops, especially during the cut scenes  2) Very High Texture settings have lot of issues  3) Game got stuck a couple of times, and i had to 'end-task' it    Hopefully they fix it soon.
Rise of The Tomb Raider set the bar high for 2016

Finished the campaign, all the tombs, and collected most of the optional stuffs like the challenges in over 23 hours, but it can take over 30-40hrs to 100% the game.  Great sequel to an already great return of Lara Croft on the 2013 Tomb Raider™ reboot. It's a bigger and a longer game than the first one. The game brings you to various huge and gorgeous environments, filled with (optional) tombs to explore and many treasures/relics to find. The level designs were improved as well from the first game, as the level are usually big and you can choose to stealth or go run and gun into battle where you can use the surroundings to your advantage, such as climbing trees, and crafting things from stuffs you pick up (even new outifts for Lara! Wow!).   The story is just fine, nothing too special, as it also brings you to Lara's dark past as well as the current events of trying to unearth the lost city of Kitezh and she faces a lot of difficulties to get there. There are more tombs in the game than before and they are optional and you have to find the secret entrance to the tomb, which are usually not that secret anyway. The tombs' design could be better as they could've made better puzzles to solve the tombs and a little increase in the number of tombs wouldn't hurt, as I left unsatisfied after the game finished, as I wanted more tombs to explore.   Pros: - Great, gorgeous environments  - Well optimized for a stable 60fps experience - Good balance between combat and platforming - Great action set pieces throughout the game - More tombs, new game mechanics - Great soundtrack and graphics  Cons: - AI is still a bit weak, even on the higher difficulties - Story could be better - Boring collectibles that makes you not want to 100% the game - A bit too easy, even on higher difficulty   RATING: 9/10  - the pros outweigh the cons  Shoutout to my friend, follower, subscriber, and loyal viewer, ajigapar aka ajipagar aka backseat gamer. #2 Shoutout to my favourite weaboo, friend, follower, subscriber, but not a viewer, Aoi-Chan aka BearDown for One Exam.

Rise of the Tomb Raider is the sequel to the reboot of the Tomb Raider franchise that launched 2 years ago. ROTTR takes what was awesome about the first game and gives it a complete upgrade while introducing new mechanics to make it feel like a sequel. I'll go into a little more detail down below.  Pros:  More of a survival orientated game.  Wildlife are more of threat than ever now.  Be careful where you tread.   Crafting is now introduced, allowing you to craft special ammunition with resources you have gathered throughout the enviroment - great incentive to explore and gather what you can.  Cut scenes, motion capture and voice acting are some of the best I've ever seen in a game  Big effort went into the level design, levels are beautiful with great variation. From the cold, icy Siberia to the deserts of Syria.  Graphics are really big step up. Definately a treat to look at if you have a higher end setup.  Quite a few new mechanics are introduced giving multiple new ways to engage enemies as well as adding replay value.   Tombs and puzzles are definately more challenging than the 2013 reboot and require a bit more thought, but they are not nearly as difficult as some of the earlier games.  Story is great. There is always that feeling that you want to see what happens around the next corner.   New characters definately add to the Tomb Raider universe while giving great possibilities for a sequel  Cons:  Overpriced DLC. The DLC for this game is really over priced. Pick the extra content up on a sale if you really want to try it out.  AI can act in strange ways sometimes.  Anti aliasing isn't that great.    Overall a great game, definately pick it up if you are a fan of the franchise. While not a true Tomb Raider game, it is still a worthy sequel

My feelings about Rise of the Tomb Raider are mixed. On one hand there is this greatly detailed world that I enjoyed exploring to the last corner and it was so visually appealing that I couldn’t stop taking screenshots of it. There is the alternative history that is worth listening to in its entirety and the quality gameplay which manages to combine survival, stealth, combat and platforming in a deadly mix of diversity. On the other hand is the highly unentertaining story filled with forced coincidences and Deus ex machina moments. There are severe performance problems which haven’t been fixed even after three patches (it's time for DirectX 12?!). And to top things off, there is a Season Pass that costs more than half of the game’s price for just three DLCs and like this wasn’t enough a microtransactions system for some useless cards. All these problems salt the wounds opened with the announcement of a timed exclusivity for Xbox One.  I like the new series and the new humanized Lara Croft. But waiting almost three years for Rise of the Tomb Raider for a slightly improved game is not ideal, especially when we have to put up with a studio that doesn’t seem to value its fans. But at the end of the day the quality of the game experience comes first and Rise of the Tomb Raider reached only part of its great potential.   Pros: + High quality gameplay + Impeccable level design + Gorgeous graphics + Good sound design, music and voice acting + Better contoured survival elements + A wide variety of skills, weapons and upgrades + Completists heaven  Cons: - Horrible optimization problems - Generic story with predictable moments - Easy - Way too many scripted events - The shooting mechanics still need work - Out of place microtransactions  Read the full review at:  http://thegameslashers.blogspot.ro/2016/02/rise-of-tomb-raider-review.html

Honestly, this is a must buy. It doesn't matter what games you play or what genre you like, you have to play this masterpiece. It's a great game not because it's innovative, not because it's memorable, not because it's deep and thought provoking and certainly not because it has a deep story. It's great simply because it is; I've tried my best to find problems and I just couldn't find much! There's no reason not to play this.   Pros:       Platforming is easy, accessible and a lot of fun     Voice acting is perfect, characters sound very real     Visuals are astonishing, the game looks gorgeous     A lot of content to explore and main story is rather long     Good replay value with expedition mode     Expansive video options on PC    Good crafting system and deep customization    The hair animation looks beautiful and very realistic     Well written dialog and good story    Optional challenges and cards system    Effective stealth system     Puzzles are very well done     Cons :     Completely pointless micro transactions    Gun sound effects are horrible, one of the worst    Very CPU intensive, unstable framerate     Long loading time    Gameplay = 9/10 ; Visuals = 8.5/10 ; Audio = 8/10 ; Music 8/10 ; Story = 9/10   Verdict : 9/10 - Great I would highly recommend this game to anyone, it's a perfect example of game development done right. The is just too good, there very few problems therefore no reason not to recommend it.

Awsome Game.  Another Lara Game another great adventure. Awsome places with a stuning WOW effect. More Tombs and Treasures to finde, more skills and weapons to finde, use and upgrade. Gameplay, Survival mode and DLC Quests for more fun. More then 20h playtime on Single Player.  Pro: Stuning Graphic Details of the Map and Tombs Soundtrack exciting Gameplay A lot to finde (weapon parts, treasures) Less shooting then in TB 2013 Survival Mode 4 different difficulty stages long playtime a lot of puzzels to solve hunt animals or collect bears to build arrows and more  Con: A few abilities are like using cheats. Servers are realy bad and you need them to open your Card bags.  9 of 10 points  About the DLC Baba Yaga:  Gameplay Time is ~2 hours, depending if you only play the mission or also search treasures to collect. its similar to the normal missions, and also include an Boss Fight. if you love Tomb Raider I would recommand to buy the SP so you can save a bit money, you also can waite on a Sale since you dont realy need to do this DLC immediately.

More Tombs to explore, More puzzles, better writing, fantastic graphics and it is a blast to play. As a long tim Tomb Raider fan, this game is alot more enjoyable than the last Tomb Raider game from 2013. I thought the last one had cool controls and nice graphics but was missing alot of the aspects that make TR enjoyable for me. I wanted more tombs to adventure in and more puzzles to solve, this game has started that thankfully.  The PC version runs well and looks gorgeous, another good PC version from the guys who did the PC port for Deus Ex HR, the latest Hitman and the latest Thief, all had good PC versions. Thank god they didn't pull an Arkham Knight with this one like WB did last year. This is a very competent PC version that looks good and runs well.  The atmosphere is also well done, really pulling you into the life of a Tomb Raider. I played this on xbox one before, now playing it on PC, I must say they have done a real nice version of this game for PC users. Pretty much a better version of the last Tomb Raider game, with some smaller improvements to bring back some of the feeling of the old TR games. This series is def heading in the right direction, not perfect yet but heading there! Get ready to try and survive the cold winter!

There's a fairly easy test here: When playing Tomb Raider 2013, did you think 'This is fun but man I hate these obnoxious QTEs and wish there were more/better puzzle tombs'? If yes, you should buy Rise of the Tomb Raider. When playing TR2013, did you think 'This was the worst decision I made since I tried to lick that opossum'? If so, don't buy Rise. If you never played TR2013, go buy that instead -- it gets down to like $5 these days on sales.  Rise of the Tomb Raider is an improved take on the 2013 game. As noted, the QTEs that plagued the first hours of TR2013 are gone, the pacing moves better and there's the usual improvements in tricks of the trade. The story is nothing special: Lara has found a lead on an artifact her father ruined his life and career trying to find and so now she plans to redeem his legacy by acquiring the Divine Source. The game is set mainly in Siberia with you traversing numerous forests, caves, lost settlements and abandoned Soviet installations under varying degrees of snow and ice. For the most part, game play is straight forward and you likely won't get stuck on what to do next for long; objects you can interact with are either splashed with white paint or glow when you use your Tomb Raider Spider-sense. Puzzles are better than in TR2013 but still nothing difficult -- I completed all with minimal issue and I'm pretty poor at physics puzzles. Combat in the game usually seems to favor stealth (you'll silently fire your bow a lot) but only in terms of killing enemies. It usually isn't practical or possible to sneak through and you'll be expected to bloody your hands often.  As a rollicking and action-filled archeological adventure, Rise of the Tomb Raider was a fun time. If you're hoping for real puzzlers and mind twisters, you'll likely be disappointed. Nothing about the game demands that you play it right now but (assuming you liked TR2013) you'll likely enjoy it when you get to it.

Rise of the Tomb Raider which is the sequel of Tomb Raider series is becoming the most attractive and wanted game for mostly it's fascinating dynamic GFX, interesting story and brilliant gameplay. I am impressed with the great story it tells. There is much more adventures than Tomb Raider 2013. It has more than my expectations. This title definitely worth 59.99$ as Tomb Raider worth 19.99$. You can't even guess how much amazing and fabulous is it. Though i completed the story with much time to feel the every moment of this game. I already can say it's gonna be awarded for Game of the Year 2016. Because it deserves something great and massive. Well, now i am gonna share my opinion and experience about this title.  Story As we have experienced the story of Tomb Raider 2013 which was mind blowing. But i have to say Rise of the Tomb Raider got far better story then ever. It's like reaching Lara's destination to discover divine source and uncover the truth what her father couldn't made it before his death. So it was Lara's destination to know the reason of the death of her father. So still there are so much barricades to stop Lara and find the Divine Source before her. She have to face something terrible with betrayal and conspiracy. So it was quiet attractive to live the story of Lara Croft in Rise of the Tomb Raider. I hope you are not gonna be disappointed.  Graphics Quality I just stopped to take breathing when i watched the GFX of this game. It's seems so amazing and great. Never saw that sun light effect and skyline in other games. I took more than 100+ snapshots when i was in the top of the mountain. I thought The Witcher 3, Assassin's Creed Unity and Assassin's Creed Syndicate got the most attractive GFX ever. But Rise of the Tomb Raider failed me this time, that just crossed all other renowned games and became the most incredible. Developers really worked hard to polish facial work in this game. I can see they applied few numbers of facial layers on the face to make it more and more realistic. That was quiet more than my expectations for GFX of this title. Finally i got something like my taste.  Pros : 1. Remarkably Optimized Game 2. Stunning Dynamic Graphics Quality (GFX) 3. Adventurous and Brilliant Story 4. Detailed and Fascinating Gameplay 5. Interesting and Useful New Features 6. Enjoyable Combating and Actions  New Features and Gameplay I found few new features in this one. Like Expedition. Expedition allows us to reply any of the chapters with Score Attack or Chapter Reply or Chapter Reply Elite. We can earn credits by completing their given objectives by replying those chapters. We can upgrade ourselves to reach a bit higher in the leaderboards. Also there is Play Card which we can use through chapters. I also got few new outfits, some of them were gonna be unlocked by progressing on story mode and some of them were gonna be unlocked by completing their given tasks. But i just loving her Leather Jacket and Grey T-Shirt, these two suits her amazingly and She looks so beautiful and innocent. Well, that's what she is, too innocent and determined. There are few more upgrades available for Bow, Pistol, AK-47, Shotgun and Axe. Now i am gonna say about the Grappling Axe which helps us to grapple ledge if we fall from it or if we have to reach somewhere quickly. We can still use Axe to make finisher or melee attack as always. You can choose four types of difficulty in game like Adventurer, Tomb Raider, Survivor. I completed the game on adventurer difficulty because i had to feel it's story amazingly. Not just wanna die again and again for hard difficulty. I got many puzzles to be done to progress story more then Tomb Raider 2013.  Optimization I have to say this is one of the best optimized games ever. They optimized it so brilliantly. Really loved it. i played this game with Very High settings and 1920X1080 resolution. Everything were maxed out, Even i maxed out Anti-Aliasing for best experience. My FPS crossed 135+ when i reached Syria. But averagely FPS stays between 60-80. My configuration : Intel Core i5 4690K, RAM 8GB DDR3, R9 290 Vapor-X 290 4GB GDDR5 OC Version with S2240L 1080P display. Well that's all happened with me, so don't know about your experience. Just said my opinion about it's brilliant optimization.  Error, Crashes, Bug, Stuttering Well, my gameplay experience was so smooth as hell, there was no error or crashes like Assassin's Creed Syndicate, no bugs, no stuttering. They made it just remarkable. There was no unexpected shut downs what bothers you the most of all. Just stunning as hell.  My Opinion and Ratings on this masterpiece : Story : 8/10 Graphics Quality (GFX) : 10/10 Gameplay : 8/10 Optimization : 10/10 Combats and Actions : 8/10 New Features : 9/10 OVERALL : 9.3/10  So i hope you are not gonna be regreted if you have planned to purchase this masterpiece. Remember, Rise of the Tomb Raider worth more than 59.99$. Highly recommending so try it if you can.(CROFT)

After finishing the campaign, all the tombs and almost all challenges, I will try to just name a few items that I consider important for the analysis, not detail every aspect of the game.  - The game is a little bigger than the last. I played for 36 hours to end the campaign and 90% of extra content. Dispending 40 hours you can make 100% of the game. Very good, but not consistent with the information of the producers 'would take 35 hours just for the campaign'. I estimate that the campaign can be completed in about 15-20 hours.  - The voice acting is great. Lara's voice with an English accent is beautiful. The sound effects are perfect. The soundtrack is almost imperceptible, with no memorable melodies, and only those ambient sounds, a little disappointing.  - Visually, it is one of the most beautiful games ever created. The optimization is reasonable, and fails in the shadow effects (very demanding and even at maximum quality are pixelated, Skyrim type). In open areas the frame rate drops significantly. The internal areas are much more beautiful, and you will find yourself often admiring every detail and forgetting to play. Lara's movement is impeccable, interacting with the environment and the situation (cold, fear, danger, stealth, etc). Her modeling is awasome, many polygons and without any 'square curves', leaving Lara more beautiful than ever.  - The story is interesting, but like most games of the genre, are simple, short and predictable. The theme comes to religious fanaticism, that doctrine the faithful and leaves susceptible to manupulaion by people and nefarious corporations.  - The optional tombs are the best thing in all game, in my opinion. Pure exploration, puzzles and beautiful scenery based on the Byzantine era. The game has more exploration than the previous one and the Uncharted series, which is great. There are still many exaggerated action scenes, such as the common clichés: walkway breaks during the passage, you fall and be safe in a wall of ice that break too, will roll to the edge of a cliff and clings on the edge, one helicopter launches a missile at you, breaks the platform and luckily you fall into a pit. I personally do not like these impossible sequences, and I think the studios could use their resources in more areas of exploration.  - There are various clothes available for Lara, but without much variety, perhaps due to the cold environment. They are all coats and long sweaters and pants only. I could not pick a really cool outfit, and ended up leaving the less boring one.  - The enemy AI is weak, getting too exposed all the time. I have killed more than 90% of them with head shots. It's frustrating because several improvements available for weapons and skills to show themselves useless. Only with the initial makeshift bow you can finish the game without difficulty. You do not feel any need to improve your weapons.  - The expansion packs coming in the season pass are ABSOLUTELY DISPENSABLES. Strongly recommend that you do not spend your money on it. Only an additional mission, which is boring, some clothes, and two game modes that you will probably never play.  Rate 8.5 / 10 - Recommended (no season pass)

+ Graphics + Crafting + Different explosives + Stealth Kills + Cutscenes + Story Line + Weapon Upgrades + Challenges + Difficult tombs  Its like a combination of Assasins Creed and Metal Gear Solid (weapons with stealth kills). Note: You need to wear headphones when you play this game, your family might think you are watching porn when lara gets hurt or something
+Lara Croft +Stunning visuals +Good story +You can throw chickens to the face of the enemies  Great game 9/10.

Rise of the Tomb Raider is a brilliant additon to the Tomb Raider series. Playing as a grittier, more efficient adventurer gives the player a whole new perspective on Lara Croft. With better puzzles, more interesting and interactive combat and a highly engaging story, Rise of the Tomb Raider makes for an amazing successor to Tomb Raider 2013. Adding much better stealth mechanics to the game provides the player with a whole new way to play the game. However, the game has a particularly short main story. Overall, Rise of the Tomb Raider is a superb addition to the already fantastic Tomb Raider game series.

Incredible game. The optimisation is pretty well. There is a satisfying amount of options available and I haven't noticed any stuttering or weird drops in framerate.  Everything is good about this game, The story is excellent. The voice acting is pretty good and the cutscenes are well done. Mouse and Keyboard Controls work perfect. The whole game looks absolutly stunning both in gameplay and during cutscenes. Also, while it's not an open world game, you'll be able to explore the areas around you in a fairly free manner.   The Graphics on max settings are insane. The Level of Detail on Lara and the World is Top of the Line and the Animations of Humans and Animals are very good. The game has gorgeous visuals and graphics, Best Visuals since Witcher 3.  If you liked the last one (2013's version), you'll love this one without a doubt.

Improves and expands on the first TombRaider reboot from 2013 but that's not to say that one was a bad game, this lets you do more and gives you more to do. Nearly 50 hours for my playthrough of the main story with almost 100% completion. Some strange graphics glitches but for nvidia I got around them by tweaking the driver setting, do all of this  http://i.imgur.com/0bbPXjR.png   Definitely worth a play and consider the croft manor DLC, I'll get to it next, but all the season pass crap can be skipped.

Pretty cool game. Great successor to the 2013 reboot. Everything that made the 2013 great has been perfected. Performance, visuals and gameplay are all perfect. Few different styles to play to suit your taste Lots of work gone into level design and environnents.  Only a couple things to pick at. Story is a bit cliche and often quite predictable. Not to say i dont like it but i was expecting something a bit more considering the 2013 story was quite good. Option to add/remove weapons mods has been removed so you're forced to use the mods as soon as you acquire them. That aside, it's worth a play through. Keen for the next one

You often hear how AAA games don’t have the kind of pre-production time you’d expect, with projects often going into full production before anyone has a clear idea of what they’re making. Rise of the Tomb Raider feels like one of those games, as most of its story is thin and poorly thought out.  I was excited to play Rise of the Tomb Raider, being a fan not just of the last game, but the series as a whole. With the last game the devs raised the bar, creating a very interesting jumping off point for future installments. Unfortunately they don’t seem to have had any good idea for where the series is supposed to go. What you end up with here is a hodgepodge of ideas from Uncharted and Assassin’s Creed, with most of what happened in the last game completely forgotten.  When you’re in control of Lara, the game feels just as good as the last game. The feeling of climbing, sliding, shooting etc is all very well done, and it’s no problem at all that this basically plays exactly the same as last time. They haven’t run this system into the ground just yet. The way the game is paced feels perfect, with all the different elements getting just enough screen time for maximum effect. In general this feels like a better game to play than the last one, and is a big part of why I enjoyed this game despite the story being disappointing.  You just can’t make the exact same game a second time, wrap a different story around the systems, and expect it to come out the other end in a coherent manner. In Rise of the Tomb Raider I couldn’t buy into the villains, or Lara, or her allies, or the setting, or almost anything that was going on in the story. I liked the ideas on kind of an abstract level. But the way the story plays out is borderline incomprehensible. Events seem to happen out of order, and characters are as thinly developed as it’s possible, with audio logs acting as an emergency measure to add motivation and depth (in a way that does NOT work btw).  In the last game, Lara made sense to me. As the violence escalated, her willingness to go along with it made sense, as she was turning more feral, looking less and less like a normal person. In cutscenes the contrast between her wildness and her companions became more and more extreme. In Rise of the Tomb Raider that Lara seems to be gone. In every scene she seems kind of normal, even in later parts of the game. She doesn’t go through any kind of journey like last time, nor does she seem to have any baggage left from the previous game, which is strange. Much of the her motivation this time is around her father’s legacy, and the things he left undone before his death. Remember that father figure mentor guy from the last game? Because this game didn’t. The more I think about the details in the story, the less it all makes sense. Like doesn’t she love historic artifacts? Then why are many of the challenges designed around destroying them? I didn’t do some of them because it felt like sacrilege. One moment the native villagers directly say to Lara that she’s a friend, just before she goes off and robs their ancient tombs within eyesight of the village. Is she just pulling the wool over their eyes? Is this some allusion to how the British empire managed to spread back in the days? She tricks everyone into thinking she’s a friend, all while robbing them of their historic artifacts and leaving the rest in a pile of dust. The story doesn’t acknowledge this aspect at all.  Part of the appeal of the Tomb Raider series is getting to explore old mysterious ruins in exotic locations. They kind of botched part of that here, as you visit old soviet era factories and interact with locals who somehow all speak English without an accent. One of my favorite moments of Uncharted 2 was when you’re in Tibet and is led by a guide who doesn’t know a word of English. The environments in Rise of the Tomb Raider are very similar, but they for some reason decided that the people of North Asia should just look exactly like the island dwellers in the last game. Feels like they’re wasting the potential of the setting and kind of missing the point of making a game like this. They might as well have set the game in Canada instead if they weren’t interested in presenting other cultures to the player. Instead you get a strange contrast between the ruins & artifacts right next to the supposed descendants of those cultures still living there, not displaying any resemblance to those cultures in any way whatsoever. I’m just guessing this stems from the project being so poorly thought out before they started making it. If they knew in advance where the story was going to take place, they probably wouldn’t have made them like this.  But for all my complaints, I still had a great time playing Rise of the Tomb Raider. The way the exploration and combat feels is about as good as you can get from the genre right now. Just being in the world, looking at it, moving through it, hearing it, are all critical aspects for a game. And this game nails all that. Some of the set pieces feel overindulgent, throwing in more explosions than the story had earned. But when the finale rolled around, the way it built up to a crescendo of everything exploding and falling apart was very nicely done. I was hoping for more, but even so this is an easy recommendation. It’s highly unlikely you’ll have a bad time with this. It just doesn't inspire any confidence that the series will ever top the last one.

Tomb Raider  series have always been able to find their fans, looking forward to a new game. The main character Lara Croft's seeking adventures throughout the world and reveals unknown mysteries, explores tombs and caves.  The series were indeed popular, so there were 2 Tomb Raider movies released in 2001 and 2003. Lara Croft was portrayed by beautiful Angelina Jolie, who was following trails left by her father. To be honest, potential of Tomb Raider franchise could have been used way better. Everything was fine, but not exciting at all. More climbing, more tombs were missing, basically we know Lara Croft in a better light.  Back to videogames. In 2013,  Square Enix  and  Crystal Dynamics  took this title into a whole different level. In collaboration with Nvidia they managed to improve the graphical side of the game. They’ve begun with a brand new story. Improved gameplay. We’re getting more detailed Lara. She’s leaving her known Dual Pistols and places more importance on a bow and stealth. Playthrough is way easier with the new Survival Instinct. Tomb Raider was definitely surprising and many of us were looking forward to continuing.  And now, here is the sequel,  Rise of the Tomb Raider . It may sound a bit unbelievable, but the developers improved the already amazing graphics from 2013. The game looks insane even on lowest video settings, and Very High is a heaven for screenshoters. Characters look very realistic with sick voices and communication, the environment is breathtaking and you might stop at a view to take a screenshot so many times.  Despite the fact that the game works on the same basics as the previous one, there are few new details making the gameplay more enjoyable. One of the most important news are resources, which can be gathered throughout the world and further used for crafting arrows, equipment, upgrades etc. Of course the ammunition can be picked up directly, but you should barely run out of ammo during combat thanks to the crafting ability.  The story is quite good, although I have to say it takes after a regular FPS. From adventurous Lara Croft seeking for historical artifacts becomes a woman seeking for revenge, anyway, let’s see what the next sequel will bring us. Unlike the first game, there are more optional tombs, some of them are easier, some of them more difficult. In fact if you’re going for 100% game completion, you have to collect all relics, documents, caches and go through every single tomb and cave. Should take about 30 hours of playtime.  Back in Main Menu I recommend trying Extra Game Modes, thanks to which you’re able to replay earlier chapters of the story, or play any mission of your own volition. The game is enriched by Expedition Cards, which can be bought for credits. Credits are earned for completing challenges, exploring the world or completing Game Modes mentioned above. These Expedition Cards further modify your missions, either they become an advantage or disadvantage and in combination with high difficulty can give you a really hard time.   For current price of 50€ Rise of the Tomb Raider offers an unforgettable gaming experience. If you fell in love with 2013’s Tomb Raider, there is really nothing to wait for. The game will pay off and you’re going to wish it’d never end.  Enjoy the game!  Matezz
Rise of the Tomb Raider

Where to begin. This is a bit of an odd one because I don't like how it's either a positive or negative as I'm rather indifferent about this game having finished it. The first game of the reboot was good, if a little tedious at times, but it left me wanting more...Until the exclusivity BS happened. I'm glad I won this in a community competition rather than paying outright for it. So, to business.  It's a solid game.  It begins with a VERY linear series of sections which introduces you forcibly to the game's crafting and forraging mechanics - my first major frustration as initially this is tedious and contrived, and later irrelevant because you never run out of resources used to craft 'special ammo' such as poison or flame arrows. The rest of the first act is once again survivor Lara VS wild and a slow progression to introduce some main characters - perhaps a little too slow, but there's enough to be doing.  Next thing to talk about is the 'extra stuff' in the game. Here I refer to the 'tombs', 'challenges', 'coin caches', 'artifacts' and audio logs. While the flesh out the story and can add a little context to what is going on, particularly with regards to the audio logs, I rarely found myself ever wanting or even caring to seek and complete challenges, find murals to learn languages to find artefacts or optional tombs. As, they are just superfluous. A nice addition, but so out of the way they're just... there? Which really is a shame because the tombs this time around were much more plentiful, had challenges in order to reach them and were then well designed physics puzzles (if a little straight forward) once you found them. The rewards were ok as well I suppose, but again, I could go throught eh game and not really care for them. In fact as it turned out I found a number early on that I could not access because I didn'thave the necessary gear yet, but never found myself thinking 'I've got to go back now and do that tomb' - this is also a comment on the difficulty of the puzzles - there's no lateral thinking and no exploration of the tombs. You see what is presented and where you need to go, it's very logical, but enjoyable nontheless.  The setting is good - I enjoyed the scenery and vistas. Graphics are good, sound design is good. Though the 'grunts' need a bit more variety in voicing I feel. The same goes for enemy variety - this needs working on and using a single posion arrow usually works with heavily armoured enemies with shields. Shooting gallieries can also be seen a mile off however I like the way at times the game gives you the option to stealthily dispatch a series of foes. Lara still feels a little clunky to move and control and is a little unpredictable at times too, but largely ok. The set-pieces in this game are pretty enjoyable as well. Damn I love trebuchets. That's the thing with this game - it's oozing with atmosphere but as a result is very linear.  Story - errr, ok? I suppose? Motivated by restoring her family's reputation you set off. The usual predictable betrayals occur and a certain character might as well have had a neon sign over their head saying who they were it was that damn obvious. All in all though it was an enjoyable story though the ending kind of happened. All of a sudden there's a shooting gallery, a super easy stealth section, a boss fight, execution and an ending cutscene that ... happens. Which was a shame because the last game managed to build up the finale - it was different to the rest of the game and you KNEW it was the finale. You could infer it here, but it just felt a bit off - if you play it you'll know what I mean.  Btw - Sequel bait is a thing here... shamefully so.  All in all - I recommend it, but when it's on sale as I do not condone their exclusivity nonsense.

First off, I recommend the game in principle. It is a good game with a good story.   Story   The Rise of the Tomb Raider continues after the previous Tomb Raider game. The difference now is that, where the previous game (TR) develops Lara as an adventurer, this game (TRofTR) assumes that Lara is already established and therefore there is no character development. The most complex character, in my mind, was the main antagonist. The story itself is generally generic. A secret society tries to find an artefact that will help them take over the world and Lara must stop them.  Spoiler: she does.   Gameplay   As before there are open areas in which you can explore, with faster paced action sequences in between. I enjoyed the open spaces, foraging for supplies, crafting, upgrading my weapons and skills. I must admit though, that I wanted some more action sequences. Death is also not as cringe worthy. You fall off things a fair amount and presumably die, but there isn’t that same sense of being truly scared and being forced to survive as in TR. Yes, I know she grew, but I missed that same urgency that drove you on and on (or something similar to that effect).   Conclusion   It is difficult for me to review TRotTR without having TR in the back of my head. On a technical level TRotTR is far better. Larger environments, more tools and weapons, more options. Better graphics. But story-wise the previous one was better. Lara is just an effective and capable killing machine. The enemies are almost, to a man, all masked, so dehumanised. The main antagonist, however, was painted well and had my empathy.    Open questions to the developers:     Please lose Jonah. He’s annoying and, while I suppose he is required to ground Lara, he did nothing in either games. At least give him his mow hawk back so that he may look bad ♥♥♥ if not act it. Otherwise, if she must have someone to support her, introduce new characters more to the like of Conrad Roth or Angus Grimaldi.   Revaluate whether an “archaeologist” (adventurous or otherwise) would use an actual 1000-year-old authentic trebuchet to destroy the gates of a 1000-year-old city in order to get inside (amongst other autrocities). The amount of destruction of a so far hidden and unknown culture was truly horrific to experience. Puzzles are all well and good, but what’s the point if there is nothing left of the culture to document afterwards?

Rise of The Tomb Raider – what can I tell about this game? First of all, it is one of the best games of the tomb raider series I've ever seen (otherwise I wouldn't recommend it), the graphics of this game are incredible, the physics of the game are awesome and the story is quite interesting. I don't think I need to tell you about the game because everyone is knows already who is Lara Croft and what the story is about, because always it's going to be a one scared girl that becomes brutal and always near death, but somehow survives and kill everybody – Good old Tomb Raider. There are new features in the game, now you can throw chicken on everybody and with special cards you can even shoot it. Lara croft becomes spider man and now she can raise her climbing axe with a rope and fly from building to building. The only minus of the game that if you fall down to death the main character falls with a little buggy way, speaking of deaths, if she falls on thorns or you let someone kill you in action there will be a 5 second movie about her death.  I think it's all i had to say about this game :) now its up to you!

This isn't a review as such, I just wanted to give my overall impression of the port for those interested. My set up: GTX 970 i7 4790K (OC to 4.2GHz) 8GB Ram @1080p  Update - With SMAA on and everything else maxed (including triple buffer) the game runs at around 45-60fps (The texture detail appears to also be very demanding. I would recommend playing on High instead of Very High to save about 20 fps, with small differences.)  The game runs at around 40-45 Fps with max setting (except shadows turned off, V-synch set to double instead of triple buffer and msaa at x2 instead of x4 - this includes HBAO+ on and textures on very high etc. This seems to be a good port, but a demanding one all the same. I'd recommended anyone with a lower system than me, or people with a similar set up looking to get 60fps, to turn the hair effects off as I have heard they are demanding. HBAO+ is supposed to also be demanding too. Especially to those with AMD set ups. If you own an AMD system I can't confirm how this game runs with AMD, but Tomb Raider (2013) was pretty well optimised for AMD aswell as NVidia so hopefully this is the case with the sequel too. (Minus all the Gameworks NVidia features).   Overall seems like a solid port. I may update this with an actual review after I've played the game for a few hours.

I dont have a strong pc, infact for gaming its kinda crappy (laptop)  i5-4210m  intel hd graphics 4600 8gb ram  However, on the LOWEST settings possible, I can still run it at an ok frame rate with alot of tweaking and getting past the linear intro. So far its been a good game, Ive been waiting for this the moment I finished the reboot from 2013.  The biggest down side is that since my graphics card is integrated (not strong at all), It cant run the facial features of alot of the characters. Im seeing however that the farther in the game I get (even though its not that far) the easier I can run it.   With that all said, RTTR is a very solid game so far and Im excited to see where it goes. Totally recommend.
