Undertale, “the friendly RPG where no one has to die.” When a game makes you feel bad for killing monsters and makes you consider not killing any more, then it definitely does something right!   Story

Upon first discovering it, Undertale seemed like a neat little game, with its promises of 'you don't have to kill anyone' and 'you can date a skeleton.' When I got around to playing it, though, I went in as a skeptic; sure, a lot of people on my Steam friends list were giving it high praise, but I had doubts that it could really be THAT good. After two playthroughs (one neutral and one 100% pacifist), I can safely say that it really is THAT good. This review will probably be a bit vague, but I don't want to spoil a single important moment of the game.  That being said, this is not a game that will hook you from minute one. The game as a whole is deeply inspired by--almost a love letter to--the Earthbound/Mother series, and the opening scenes reeked a bit of trying way too hard to emulate those excellent, beloved games. Undertale takes a little while to find its own voice, and it does eventually reach the point where its unique style and charm becomes fully realized.  In particular, the game masterfully shifts gears between hilarious and heartwrenching, and wacky and reverent, sometimes in the same scene! A few jokes fall flat, of course, but this game had me smiling and laughing way more than any other game in recent (or even not-so-recent) memory. The characters are delightful, and the gags can be both groanworthy and genuinely hilarious. The more serious, emotional scenes still don't feel out of place, though--the changes in tone never feel abrupt or out of place.  The story and characterization are incredible. Just trust me on this. The only thing I'll point out here is that I love how the main character was designed. This character is androgynous and never assigned a gendered pronoun, which I think is really nice!  The music is incredible, too.  Gameplay of Undertale feels secondary to the plot in terms of importance, but it's still just as fantastic as the rest of the game. It's a somewhat ecclectic mix of strategy (How can I end this battle peacefully?) and bullet hell-inspired dodging sequences done in WarioWare-sized chunks. Battle encounters against each of the game's enemies are all well-crafted; boss fights are fun challenges, with most offering their own unique spin on the basic game mechanics.  Calling Undertale 'a labor of love' doesn't even do it justice in my mind. This project feels like something that was in developer Toby Fox's head for a long time, and he finally managed to get it out and present it to the world. You should play it. Yes, you. It's real good.

Undertale. What to like about this game? Warning, Undertale is best played without ANY prior information. GO IN BLIND. Then you will understand what the game truly is.  -The Morality System: Your every action has consequenses. Unless you go into the game's files, the game could potentially remember you killing a single enemy and then reseting 100 times. The Game is not afraid to shatter the fourth wall, and when it does, it does so with glee.  -The Combat System: The game is a combination of traditional RPGs and Bullet-Hell shooters. You can dodge every attack if you are good enough. Also, with the ability to spare of kill any Monster you encounter, it challenges what we think of as good RPGs.  -The Story: While the story is basic at first, it is more about the characters you meet along the way. Flowey, the master of fourth wall breaking and a terrifying creature. Toriel, the motherly character who will do anything to protect you. Sans, a skeleton armed with bad puns and bad times. Papyrus, the brother of Sans who will do anything to join the Royal Guard and loves cooking spaghetti. Undyne, the leader of the Royal Guard with a hotheaded personality. Alphys, the Royal Scientist with a dark secret and a passion for Anime. Mettaton, the Killer Robot TV Host. Asgore, the king of all Monsters. Not to mention each Monster in a battle has a personality.  -The Endings: Neutral, Pacifist, and Genocide. The Three endings. I can't spoil to much, except that each ending accomplishes very different things. For Example, while Pacifist gives you a feeling of happiness, Genocide is physically and Mentally exhausting. In Genocide, you're gonna have a bad time.  -The Music: Oh My Days, the Music. Beautiful in every way.  Is this a good game? Yes. This surpassed all my expectations. 10/10.

Undertale is a game that took me by surprise and it has left an impression that will stay with me forever. It is one of those magical games that come along only so often. I loved everything about it. The music, the writing, the gameplay, the art. This is a beautiful game that has so much heart and soul. What Toby and his team have created is a classic. If you're still skeptical, please keep reading and try the demo at  http://undertale.com !  Undertale is a 'traditional role-playing game where no one has to get hurt'. If you're familiar with most any RPGs, then the basic game mechanics should feel very familiar to you. You play as a protagonist who explores a vast labyrinth, encountering monsters, engaging them in turn based combat, leveling up after gaining EXP, talking to NPCs, and solving puzzles. Despite having all these standard elements, Undertale is NOTHING like any RPG you've played before.  Despite being rather short, roughly 10-13 hours for me, each moment is precious. There's so much attention to detail and you'll find surprises around every corner. The writing is brilliant, filled with humor and wit, and at the end I was hanging on every word. Each character is rich with personality and you'll remember all of them long after you've completed the game.  The combat system is very unique and is one of the first things to stand out about the game. Confrontations are a mix between classic turn-based RPG combat and 'Shoot Em' Up' mini-games. Each enemy feels fresh and completely different from the next, and that's not even the half of it. Aside from attacking and defending, there's a lot of other fun actions you can explore. Most importantly, the option to refrain from fighting all together.  It's nothing new for a game to let you choose either a violent of pacifist approach, but Undertale takes the concept to a whole new level and is fundamental in what makes it so special. Despite placing you in the role of a vulnerable child lost in an underworld full of monsters, the game wants you to be comfortable, enjoy yourself, and learn to love the universe you're in. It does this so well, that by the end, the thought of hurting anyone or anything in this world will break your heart.  Toby Fox has single handedly risen to my top 5 game composers. He already has an impressive portfolio; you may have heard some of his earlier works from Homestuck. His range of styles and the feelings he evokes is simply astounding. The score for this game is very unique, and maintains a masterful quality all the way through.  Undertale has moved me in ways that only a few others before it could. It fosters so many strong and pure emotions. It will make you laugh and it'll make you cry. It's a world you'll want to fully immerse yourself in and for only $10 it's a steal. The memories I've made with this game are worth infinitely more. Thanks for reading my review. The thought that it may have convinced even one person to play the game fills me with determination!

An amazing and unique game, that offers the unforgettable experience while playing it. Sadly enough, I can't say the same good thing about its fandom which is regarded as toxic. Nontheless, I highly recommend getting this awesome game, as long as you won't bother with its disappointing fandom.

One of the most heartfelt and genuine games I've ever played. Undertale is an RPG where, as advertised, you don't have to kill anyone. You play as a child who has accidentally fallen into an underground society of monsters, long since locked away after an unsuccessful war on humanity.  However, despite an immediate declaration that this world is 'kill or be killed,' you are introduced to a motherly monster named Toriel who introduces you to the Ruins you have landed in, and the puzzle-based world they live in. From there, you find your own way, and decide to befriend the monsters, or whether they are deserving of your wrath, as you venture forth and find a way home.  As overly 'quirky' as the screenshots of the game may make it seems (although don't get me wrong, the game is gut-bustingly funny), Undertale's writing is top-notch. No other game has invoked so much emotion in me, in... well, ever. The game runs the gambit from heart-wrenching tragedy, to unstoppable laughter, to genuine unease, aided in part by the way the game handles YOU, as a player, and the way you interact within the world, and what sort of entity you are compared to the denizens of the underground. And on top of that, each character is unique and has a strong personality, from the bosses-turned-friends (on pacifist runs) to each and every monster you encounter.  The music is, most certainly, one of the game's strengths. Most of the game was made by Toby Fox, a musician who has composed for the popular webcomic Homestuck. Each track is crucial in setting the game's tone, and most songs will stay with you, even long after you've left the world of Undertale.  I'm really bad and awkward at writing, so if there's one thing to take away from this review, it's this:  This game has exceeded all of my expectations and made me emotionally unstable. Get it.
Just remember to be careful what you pay for, Steam can only refund monetary transactions.

This game does... strange things to people.  It somehow manages to reawaken emotions one would have never thought a game could. The music is spot-on, the dialogue and personalities of the characters are amazing, puzzles aren't particularly difficult but the occasional japes make them seem less tedious.  This game will amuse you. This game will annoy you. This game will make you angry. This game will make you sad. This game will make you hate everything. This game will make you love everything. This game will make you DETERMINED.  Even if you lack the capacity to feel emotions, this game even thought of that and has something very... special for you.
this game fills me with determination.
I'm not crying,There's something in my eye. Determination.

In a time when videogames concentrate on just being adictive, eye candy or making profits, Undertale comes and makes us remember why we love videogames so much. I played this game the days after it was released by non 'legal' methods, and holy gross, what can i say, i loved it.  The game itself its just a cute rpg like earthbound with a simple mechanic that let you spare your 'enemies' instead of killing them, but it was so well executed in a way that complements the story perfectly. The music on the other hand is fantastic, i still hear it almost every day on my way to college or when i want to chill at home.  But clearly, the most important thing about this game is that it has a lot of heart in it and you can sense that from the very first minutes of the game, its not another game that you buy and leave it in your library forever (i know i have only 8 hours on it but trust me i played it a lot more outside of steam), its the kind of game that makes you convince your friends to play it because you need to talk about it, its the kind of game that makes you search for countless covers and animations on youtube. This game its the kind of game that makes you feel like a child again, getting carried away by the characters and the world in it, making you laugh or cry.  Undertale is my kind of game, and i hope and dream that more games like that will be created in the future.  Happy Birthday Undertale.

Undertale reminds me of the time I was a kid when I could play a game with next to no preconceptions. I'd see it for the adventure that it was, the wild fantastical world that I loved to lose myself in. I didn't care about anything else, who made it, what it looked like, the genre it encompassed. Just the idea of what I thought I could find if I played it.   There are a lot of things that be can be said about the game, but I think the real thing is how the experience is so different for so many players. It seems to connect to people in a way they didn't expect it to. It is, at its core, a lovingly handcrafted experience. The best thing you could possibly do is to ignore everything else that has been said about Undertale and just play it for yourself.
It's like when we discovered Cave Story.  But even better.

I think it's a testament to Undertale's excellence that, despite my exposure to the embarassing cosplays, horrible (and at times pandering) fanart, bizarre Rule 63 alternate universe shippings, and an obsessed community that only Tumblr and anonymous image boards could create, it still managed to blow me away and leave me suprised.   Every facet of Undertale is pouring at the seams with tender care; the memorable characters, the wacky encounters, it's unpredictable gameplay and the layered soundtrack that fits perfectly with every situation. Believe it or not, this game never feels like it was made to pander; instead, it feels like it exists as a labor of love, a tribute to what makes video games in general great. Because of this, it's very easy to distance what the game actually is from whatever the heck some parts of the fanbase want it to be.  It does truly upset me that many people are so disgusted by the rabid fanbase that they're turned off from playing Undertale, but this game has a massive following for a very good reason - I myself feel horrible I waited so long to experience it. It's that very rare kind of game that I think everyone should at least give a shot.

A near perfect 9.999999/10.  The only way it could've been better is if it never ended.  A relatively simple combat system, with an interesting dodging mechanic tied to a - at first glance - no more than easy to make art style may leave passerbys assuming this is yet another half-baked indie game, but it is so much more than that.  Having beaten one of the relatively short 10 hour playthroughs, the game had left me yearning for more. I haven't played a game that has impacted me in such a way in a long time, and even fewer games have made me feel bad for even thinking about taking the easier and shorter route. From Toriel the 'goat mom' to sans and Papyrus' infamous bad jokes, Toby Fox has created memorable characters that feel more alive than just pixels on a screen. A certain flower, lesser dogs and an angry fish girl; they each react differently to your decisions and actions, which are permanent and have a lasting effect on the world you inhabit in the game. Morals are a large part of the story, and at some point, you have to make a choice. Whether you make a good one or a bad one, is up to you.  Whatever you do - whether you have an inkling of empathy or not - play this game. I am certain you will enjoy it.    ...and, don't forget. Be filled....with  DETERMINATION.
Still a pretty good game.

' Choices matter '  This tag is so missused in most games. Life is strange and The Walking Dead series are prime examples of this. They present an illusion of choice, but whatever you do (exept the last choices) will give you basically the same results.  Undertale however, is the only game where I have felt that my actions truely tailor my story. The game remembers what you have done hours ago, or even in previous playthroughs  Do not be discouraged by the simple graphics or the slow start. This game is so deep not even Adele could roll in it.

I just beat the game and got the true Pacifist ending maybe 20, 30 minutes ago and I haven't even closed it yet. It's just sitting there, the end title displayed and the music playing serenely in the background.  Undertale is something really, really special. I laughed until I cried, I bawled my eyes out (three times), I sat and stared and shouted aloud in genuine horror. This game pulls so many sharp turns on the emotional roller coaster that I could barely keep up. Its characters grabbed hold of my heart and held on tight, and I have a feeling they'll be sticking around for a good while now.  This game is the best I have ever played. I don't think words can properly describe it. It's left me with that gaping void that any good entertainment leaves behind, video game or otherwise. I haven't felt like this in years, easily.  Please, if you are on the fence about buying this game, I urge you. Please, buy it. You're missing out on something extraordinary.

To be honest when i started to play Undertale i had zero expectations, and was sceptical for its hype. Friends whom played the game were like ''Zomg when you're gonna play Undertale? You MUST DO IT!!!!!!1!!!11!'' and when i replied ''Dunno if i even want to..'' oh man, that was almost cardinal crime in their eyes.   However i never judging games before playing them hence adventure started. And after beating (probably) all endings....daaaamn...i haven't been so impressed for ages.   But first things first. Let's analyze the game.  Undertale is Indie RPG (more or less) made just by one guy, which is really impressive. Story isn't linear, it changes by your playing. Decisions you made ACTUALLY MATTERS. For every action there's consequences and that's why i love it.   Battles are interesting. Basically it's bullet hell where you try to survive. But worry not, it's not so hard as it sounds...well.. there are few exceptions but after learning pattern and with dose of determination you can do it.  The characters are so well written and have strong, unique personalities. Makes you questioning moral principes not just in the game but in real life as well.  The best thing (atleast in my opinion) is soundtrack. It's perfect for every situation which you encounter.  Summary: Pros-story, decisions, characters, soundtrack, battles, morals within story Cons- only found one SPOILERS!-   In genocide run some bosses died after one hit,it's epic,sure but c'mon i expecting to had hard time with Mettaton atleast.   ,also wish it could be a little longer...  My final verdict is 10/10! Legendary game! (Explenation: There's no thing such as 'perfect' game. However this is closest thing what i found. The story worthy of replaying it,brutally changing by your action so you feel like you're playing totally different game and i love this concept.)  So yea....i finally understand why my friends were so obsessed.   Thanks for checking the review. Stay determinated.
If you kill things you, are going to cry. If you kill everything, you are going to cry.  If you spare everything, you are going to cry.   If you play this game, you will cry.

* Let's join the hype and try this game out, I'm sure it's definitely worth the shot after all. * But no way I'll play it pacifist like all these wimpy hippies, that wouldn't be original. * 'I'll poop on the flowers and kill the monsters!' I said to my friends. * ... * Eh...   Undertale is a wonderful little nugget of pure gold. Of much higher quality than lots of triple A games.  It is a game where the only real monster you might actualy meet, depending on your way to play, is yourself. It is a masterpiece from A to Z. The storyline is really well orchestrated and a real pleasure to discover through your adventures. The whole game is filled with secrets, puns, references and other jokes that will constantly make you smile. The soundtracks are by far ones of the bests I've ever happened to hear. Every melody, every note fits its environment and situation perfectly. It is a pure and perfect osmosis. Every charachter has his own unique and strong personality, each and every one of them is amazingly attaching by his own way. You will feel truly happy for some, deeply sad for others. And some will terribly miss you...  At the end of my journey I only have one regret: knowing that this world and these wonderful charachters that I've met and love so much are finaly nothing more than bunches of pixels and lines of code. That truly breaks my heart, and that's why Toby Fox can really feel proud of what he has accomplished.   I couldn't recommand this game more, once again, it is a pure masterpiece.    * ... * ... * Glad I changed my mind at the end, pacifism always avoids some extra bad times...

'Hope and dream fill you with determination.'  Why do we like playing games? Is it because we just wanna run away from reality, or be a hero in virtual world, or just need to avoid being bored? After playing undertale, maybe you’re able to answer the question: because games fill us with determination.  Western people do value personality. Their reality shows don’t sell tragic stories, but they do tell stories, just for creating personalities. There can be a cute silly little boy, a wise elder man, a warm-hearted lady, and a mean white girl in a show. Personality is the key to make audience love a person and a show. And when I started playing undertale, the strongest feeling was “what strong personalities!”. Undertale created personality for every single character or monster, and all the personalities are strong which are so memorable. I believe it’s also the main reason why it gets so many positive comments on Steam. You may see a lot of fan art pieces on Instagram and Tumblr which is really rare for an indie game. It means a lot. Strong personalities mixing with simple graphics bring an amazing chemistry. The contrast brings bigger astonishment.  After playing games for so many years, we all have got a “pattern”: kill monsters, gain exp., level up, beat boss, end. So every time we start a new game, we just try to figure out how to attack, jump, beat enemies and what skills we will get after we up the level as soon as we can. In undertale, it seems to create the same atmosphere, and there are “EXP” and “LV” too. It tells you “EXP” stands for experience, and LV represents “LOVE”, so you have to beat monsters, gain “EXP” to rise your “LOVE”. You may meet monsters anytime, and it may be a frightened dog, a sad ghost, or a narcissistic horse. You have four choices: FIGHT, ACT, ITEM, MERCY, and in ACT, you may PET, FLIRT, TALK with monster, just like other RPG games! Your choices really mean a lot in fight, however, like the classic saying gose, you have to “stay determined”, especially when you choose MERCY, you will face a number of attack until the monster gives up fighting. Of course sparing others requires determination, dosen’t it? Sure, you can choose fight as well and kill the monster, even though it’s just an overwhelmed dog, a terrified bee. Playing so many games, we already become numb and ruthless and we don’t regard it weird to kill monsters and gain experience. That’s what we want actually, isn’t it?  You have to be responsible for your choices. In undertale, a little choice will probably result in a completely different end. At the beginning, you will meet Toriel who is gentle, patient, compassionate and lovely. She makes cinnamon pie for you, calls you to check if you’re safe, arrages a room for you... But we all know that we have to keep moving forward and leave the ivory tower she builds for us. So, we’ll start the fight with her. I had no idea how to end the fight for the first time, and I tried to spare her 2 or 3 times but it didn’t work at all. So I guessed I had no option but to kill her. My heart sank deeper and deeper when I saw her HP get lower. “Am I really about to kill her?” I felt horrible but couldn’t stop it so I just kept doing it. When my HP was 2 points, I found her attack was dodging me like a real mom by no means would hurt her child. Finally, I killed her, kept moving on sadly and was thinking about starting over again. After watching some playthrough I noticed that if I had chosen mercy for 20 times, Toriel would let me go then I could move on without killing her. Ultimately, it was all because I didn’t “stay determination”. There were so many cute characters afterwards, dream boyfriend sans, silly and cute THE GREAT PAPYRUS, brave and responsible Undyne, drama queen MTT, and really helpful professor.... The developer designed exclusive lines for every single character which made them alive and vivid. Due to the fight with Toriel, I spared PAPYRUS, gave up killing Undyne. However, it was too late, after killing Toriel, I was already in a hypocritical line. No matter what I did after that, I couldn’t reach the “true end”. In the final fight with Asgore, the developer just slapped in my face again. He told me “EX” was “Execution points” instead of experience points, LOVE represented “level of violence” instead of love itself. That moment, I had to admit it was really an excellent game and started regretting to do what I had done.  Undertale is filled with irony and black humor. It makes players feel empathetic. It wrapped its simple and thin fighting mode with abundant personalities. It’s like watching a movie more than playing a game. After finishing it, players will almost love every monster and can’t wait to play it again!(spare Toriel!) Besides, the soundtrack was amazing too. It really helped us feel immersed.   Anyways,  keep calm and stay determined.  9/10
I have cried twice in my entire life. Once when my grandma died, And when I finished this game. 10/10

How do I explain this game? Its like trying to describe a sunset to the blind. There's no *real* way reading any review or explanation could give you the exact feeling playing this game gives you. But I'll try to give you an idea.  When I first saw the trailer and heard of it I skipped past it a bunch. Sure I heard it was a good game, but it was some wierd 16bit thing. I'd rather play GTAV right?  Boy was I wrong.  So it comes on sale and I grab it out of sheer curiosity. Man was I in for a treat. The game itself is mechanically simple. You avoid enemy attacks with your red heart as enemies shoot varying behaving projectiles at you and then fire back by either using the 'fight' option or the 'act' option.  Its how the game handles the aftermath that makes it special. Kill a monster? It remembers that. Regret it and reload the game? The game remembers that too. You grow attached to these underground dwelling monsters, from the silly innocent Papyrus to the brave Undyne. I'm going to avoid spoilers as to how these characters develop but suffice it to say that they are all unique, likeable, and everyone is going to have their favorite. No monster down here in the underground is easily classified under evil or good. They all have stories. They all have reasons for the way they are.   The graphics aren't anything special but they don't *need* to be. This is a game about a story. This is a game where you can write  your own  story. Do you want to be the angel that saves the monsters, or the demon that destroys them? Do you want to crown someone king? Or do you wish to make no friends and simply leave this underground place.  All that can be done. By your choices. By your actions.  Don't take my word for it. I know you've been skipping past this game awhile. Maybe you keep seeing it in your front page and go 'Ugh! I already know about this game!'  Do yourself a favor. Buy it. Its worth every dollar spent and you'll remember this game for the rest of your life.

All right, this game is epic. There is just few rules you need to follow to get most out of the enjoyment.  First: DO NOT ENTER THE FANDOM WITHOUT BEING PREPARED! Most of it is darn lethal to your braincells and made even the creator to cry out 'oh god why!' Second: Do not let anyone tell you how to play this game, do it your own way. As long as you remember to read the text everything will be good to go. Third: Go through blind, if possible.  Do those and you will have epic time, rediscover your emotions you though you you didn't have anymore and lot more of things! I have yet to met anyone who dislikes this after actually playing through it and reading the texts!

Note: review does not contain spoilers. or dogs.  At it's core, Undertale is a traditional RPG. It has random battles. You gain 'EXP' and Gold. It relies on lots of dialogue and nostalgiac pixel graphics to immerse you into the story. And although I have incredibly fond memories of titles like Chrono Trigger and Secret of Evermore, I am not a big fan of traditional RPGs due to heavy use of recycled content, random battles and lengthy dialogue as it's primary means of storytelling and building atmosphere. In otherwords: there's a lot of filler, a game that could be summed up in a 2 to 3 hour cinematic will instead span 30 to 40 hours of 'grinding' and 'exploration'.  Undertale, however, is short and sweet. I completed the game in 3 to 4 hours, and that included a lot of 'exploration' and taking my time to read the dialogue, stopping to smell the roses (and dogs). Random battles aren't tedious because the combat gimmicks (dodging attacks and being able to mercy opponents) make it interesting enough. Upon playing the game a second time, I realized that running into the same combat encounter more than once was quite rare. Since enemies have different 'bullet hell' attacks, they create some interesting combos. For instance, one monster might create a circle pattern, while the other does vertical lines. Either one of those attacks by itself isn't that tough, but together it's a little more tricky. Needless to say... I've never been bored with the combat or wanted it to 'just be over with already' like I have in so many other RPGs.  The game's aesthetics are impressive as well. At a quick glance, it seems like it suffers from bland, uninspired 'indie' pixel graphics meant to invoke feelings of nostalgia for gamers of the 80s and 90s. However the art style is great and subtle facial expressions make major characters really come to life. The environments and use of colors creates a very immersive atmosphere and makes certain moments a lot more emotional. The dogs are well drawn, too. I will mention however that a lot of the NPCs aren't animated, just still images with moving mouths, but it never really felt jarring or out of place - just a bit lazy. Soundtrack is great, very quirky, Earthbound soundfont is generously used here. There's even a dog song.  The real highlight of the game, however, is the incredible writing quality. I am very picky about writing in games like these, because without a good storytelling element, RPGs are just turn-based beat'em'ups. Undertale is quite the tale. The humor is on point. The characters have really vivid personalities. There are dogs. Personally, I found the story itself to be very moving. I can't say much more about that without spoiling something, so I'll leave it at that.  Edit: I beat it again and saw the 'True Ending'. God damn. Changing my rating from B+ to A.  Overall: A Definitely worth the price ($10)

Well. This game honestly took me by surprise.  When I first saw this game, I didn't really think much of it, just another generic 8-bit RPG filled with memes, so I didn't really ever consider playing it. Then, a friend of mine gifted me it, and I didn't want to be rude and put it off, so I thought 'hey why not give it a shot?'  And so I did. Frankly I was surprised at the bullethell aspect of dodging enemy attacks in an RPG game, and I don't really mind bullet hell so I welcomed it. Boss battles are also quite unique as well. They each have their own gimmick that you have to do, IF you want to befriend them. (tip: if you want to, there is always a way to spare absolutely every enemy you encounter in the game, no matter what. You sort of have to do that on your first playthrough if you want to see the True Ending). In terms of attacks, they each put in their own unique twists in an attempt to hinder you. Frankly I really liked how all the bosses mixed it up in terms of attacks and gimmicks. Enemies are pretty interesting too  In terms of story, how should I put this? It takes a while to find its own voice, and the story seemed generic with a mild humourous twist at first. But then I got to the final few parts of the game, and the story REALLY picked up from there. VERY rarely have I ever played a game where I managed to legit feel something for the story and it's characters, and Undertale's finale did exactly just that.  NPC's are also pretty unique. A lot of them I found pretty funny, although some of the attempted humour may not appeal to some people, as they may think it tried too hard. Nevertheless, almost all the NPCs are likeable and have clear distinct personalities.  The soundtrack. The soundtrack is, quite frankly, one of the best aspects of this game. I have not found one track in here that I dislike. Just about every single one I've heard, I've loved. The best ones are the boss themes, a lot of them are a mix between retro and modern. Toby pulled off this combination in an absolutely excellent way, putting this game's soundtrack in my list of the best soundtracks I have ever heard in any videogame  Overall, would I reccomend it? It depends. If you don't mind bullet hell and retro style graphics, then this is definitely the game for you. If you don't like either as much, then I'm not sure if you will enjoy this game, but I still advise to try it out for the story/characters. This is definitely one of the better games I played this year, and I can't wait to see what'll happen if I do different things during different runs.  10/10

Before deciding to purchase it, I'd already heard a few things about Undertale. Not enough for me to really be able to form my own opinion on it, but they were good things. This was two days ago. I'd messaged my friend Bread, who was playing it at the time, inquiring as to whether or not I should buy it. The reponse I got? An immediate, emphatic 'BUY IT' followed by 'NOW', and then 'BUY IT NOW'.  Why did I ask? Was I unsure about my wanting the game? No, certainly not; as a content creator myself, I make it a point to consume media, which includes different video games. And it wasn't even a money situation, though that's a good reason not to get a game of course. Thing is, I don't buy video games for myself very often. In a respectable Steam library of around 100 games, out of the ones that cost actual money, I've purchased maybe about 10% of them, if that much. So maybe you're thinking 'wow, so how do you have so many games?' Simple: my friends and followers are very generous people.  I bought the game.  The art style itself didn't really appeal to me right off the bat. I mean yeah, some pretty cool art here and there, especially with pixel/binary backgrounds, but it wasn't for me. Still, a game is more than the first few panels you see and I gotta say I did warm up to it and it became a part of the general familiarity of the world. Though I wish to add that the introduction was beautifully rendered, featuring an intriguing (though admittedly not 100% 'original') story to lead off with. Plus AMAZING tunes.  So yeah,  I was thinking to myself,  let's check this out.   Now, I won't spoil what happens, even at the very, very start of the game. You can poke around social media for those kinds of details. But I will say that the start of it threw me off, and it certainly drove me to continue playing.  Just learning the ropes,  I thought.  No biggie.   YES biggie, holy ♥♥♥♥. When you read about Undertale and how it boasts an unusual RPG system, I mean, it really does. There are routes you can take, conversations you will go through, and events that transpire that will make you think. Not just like 'hm' kinda think, or whatever kind of thinking you assume I mean, but more about how actions have consequences.   'But Kat,'  you protest.  'I already know actions have consequences. I learned this in, like, kindergarten.'   Okay, probably. You know that what you think, say, and do is part of what culminates to make your life or whatever. But hey, I'm just saying, sometimes you need a reminder, right? Sometimes, you go through ♥♥♥♥, and it makes you think. Really think. And it makes you regret some things, and laugh, basking in the nostalgia of other things, little details that will never quite escape you. Happy and sad and frustrating things you might not forget tomorrow nor five years from now. Overall this game is that ENTIRE (very fulfilling) experience.  Also, while I'm still here, I just wanted to say: You will forever be in my heart, Toriel.   tl;dr:  Spectacular soundtrack, lovely characters you'll get attached to, unique RPG 'battle' system, memes, approximately 25 minutes worth of tears (from myself, at least), hilarious jokes, bad fonts, generally a great time.  Buy this game. Buy the soundtrack too, if you can afford it.

It has been a long time since a game actually made me give a damn about any of the characters in it, let alone ALL of the charactes in it. This game, Undertale, did that. It made me rememeber how it felt to actually enjoy video games again instead of just playing them to try and fill the gigantic void in my life and block out the bad-thoughts.   This game had me laughing, worried, nervous and deeply caring for the characters and story. It also has a fantastic soundtrack, incredible boss fights and is all-around a wonderful game.   I recommend this game strongly.

Yes you will probably cry if you like this game a lot xD I recommend it 100%.  This game truly touches your soul.   Nominated for: I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye'

It was... I don't remember what day it was. Thadeus had bought me a game he loved. Undertale it was called. For a while, I didn't really want to play it. I mean, the graphics seemed... not that impressive and all I knew about it was that it was influenced by Mother/Earthbound, which granted are some of my favourite RPG's, but for some reason, I held off on playing the game.  I sat down one day, Thadeus eagerly sitting on Steam chat, awaiting my reaction. I fired up the game, commented how I could tell it was made in Game Maker, cause of the collision detection. Commented how I wish the music wouldn't constantly change styles. I kinda half-♥♥♥ played it, not really paying full attention. I met Flowey, he of course was creepy as all hell, letting me know it was 'kill or be killed'. I killed some enemies. That's what you do in RPG's, right? I earned some EXP and felt pretty good. This character Toriel took me in, she seemed very nice. I liked her. In fact... I started to enjoy her company. Then I wanted to leave her place and move on. She blocked my way, said she was going to test if I was ready.  Then I killed her.    Realizing what I'd done, realizing I had killed a character who was friendly, I panicked. What happened? In other games, friendly NPC's wouldn't die if you fought them. They would stop, not let you kill them, something would keep it from happening. Yet here I sat, watching Toriel vaporize in front of me after the most blood chilling speech I've ever seen from someone friendly.  I cried, I felt rotten. I felt ashamed. I reloaded the game so I could get her back. The next fight the game told me I thought of letting Toriel know I watched her die, and she said she felt like a ghost when I looked at her. Finally figuring out how to spare her I moved on. Then... Flowey appeared again. He let me know he was aware I had reloaded to try and save Toriel. I felt a chill down my spine unlike anything I've ever felt in any game. I knew it was possible for game characters to break the fourth wall but this felt like Flowey was speaking directly to me. Not the sprite on the screen, but the player controlling the sprite. Instantly I felt like I couldn't play anymore. I was scared, way out of my comfort zone. I had just played a game that held me directly responsible for taking the life of a friendly character. I shut down the game and didn't touch it again for a long time...  I deleted my save file... manually... complete reset of the game... then I went back one day. Thadeus urged me to go back to it, struggling not to spoil it for me.  I had an experience that changed my entire view on games. What games can do to you, how they can impact you. Undertale takes every trope, every preconception you might have about games and turn them entirely on their heads. Instead of killing everything, you are urged NOT to kill, but to use non-violent solutions. The game has no limits on who you can kill. You can kill everyone if you so desire. It is up to you if you want to kill everyone or make friends. So on my second playthrough, scarred by my initial experience, I didn't hurt anyone. And the rest of the game was honestly one of the most unforgetable experiences I've had in gaming ever, something that will truly stick with me forever.  Undertale proves that 8bit sprites on a computer screen can feel as real as you and me, it proves that killing is a horrible thing and holds nothing back to push that point home. It proves that in the end, the only thing that matters is what you choose.  So choose wisely...

Play it.  No really, stop reading reviews and just play it. It is: -an excellent 16-bit style RPG -a game with a great soundtrack -a game with multiple ways to complete it that are fundamentally different from each other -a game that messes with you, more so than any other game.  Play it.

Do I really have to write this review? I am just one in thousands of people who wrote a positive reveiw for Garry's Mod. Chances are, this review will never convince someone to buy Garry's Mod. It'll just be lost in the 100,000 positive reviews out there. Well, here I go anyway.  'Where do I start?' This is the question asked by anyone playing Gmod for their first time. It's also my question that I ask about this review I am writing. Hmm...  _The gameplay...the gameplay...hmm... Well, there's singleplayer sandbox. You can do...uh, whatever you want really. Just addon a few addons, and you can be entertained for hours. Battle NPCs, make cool scenes for cool screenshots, explore maps, be a superhero (spiderman addon!), and much, much, much, much- you get my point, right? Almost all content is user-generated. Make your own content! Multiplayer. In Multiplayer Gmod you can roleplay. I'm talking normal RP (DarkRP), Military RP, Star Wars RP, etc, etc. In multiplayer Gmod, you can battle, prophunt (yay), hide 'n seek, and much, much, more.  _Graphics? I'll rate the graphics...drumroll please... 7/10. This game is and older game. Came out in 2006. I guess the graphics are good for 2006, and people enjoy the game and don't complain much about the graphics, but I'm not gonna lie, they are outdated and look old. It's not 2006 anymore.  _Hear the bullets flying. The zombies growling. The people chatting. The boxes jumping... The sound in this game is great! Every sound is loud and clear, and there are a varitey of sounds.  _Play this game. Play it again. Play it some more. Play some now, and play some later. Play it over and over. Play it as long as you want.  _My Personal opinion. Get this game. Now. Get Gmod on sale or not. I'm not gonna stop playing it for a while and I'm already at 50+ hours of playtime. I love this game! WAIT! Before you go and buy this, then you wonder why there are all the missing maps and errors in most games, get Counter Strike: Source, so ALL the textures are supported. You need it to play MOST multiplayer games.   Gameplay: 9/10 Graphics: 7/10 Story: N/A Sound: 8/10 Replayability: 10/10  Overall 8.5  Even though, this is one positive review on Garry's Mod, out of the thousands of positive reviews that have been submitted Garry's Mod, I hope this one convinces you to buy... Gmod  -Star_Hawk_

Garry's mod...Aah, what can we say about this little gem? This beautiful not-really-a-game-game gives you some of the most open Sandbox software ever. Not only does it give you the power to change physics and spawn gazillion NPCs at the same time, it has spawned a few of the most brilliant gamemodes, such as Trouble In Terrorist Town (TTT) and Prop Hunt. G'mod's a gem, don't even hesitate to get this one!

Despite its release date, this is still one of the best games out there, where only your imagination is the limit to what you can do.  The base game is sandbox with Half-Life 2 weapons and it supports models from most Source engine games such as Counterstrike Source, Team Fortress 2 and Left for Dead 2.  New features aswell as modifying exisiting ones can be done through modding, and the language used in the mods is lua, which is very easy to pick up on and learn.

What can you say about a mod that has about a million servers and infinite replay value with it's own workshop and fanbase?  Well, for starters. this game has everything to offer due to its unbelieveable amount of mods and mod authors, you want to blow things up? Go download a c4 charge and plant it in a fully destructable building if your computer can handle it.  Want to watch youtube videos in a theatre? Go to a Gmod theatre server.  Want to live a life in a game? Go to a RP server.  Want to roam around a nuclear wasteland filled with zombies and bandits? Go to a dayz server or another end-of-the-world server.  Want to play sherlock holmes and find the traitor among the innocent? Or be said traitor? Find a TTT server.   My point is, you want something? there's probably a mod for that. If you have a friend that can play with you on a LAN server or just a private server, get creative in sandbox. you could make something, you could create scenarios, you could pose some ragdolls for some funny or gruesome screenshots, or even just send armies of rebels against two antlion guards. The choice is yours!  Overall, this game gets an 8 out of ten from me The mod is the limit in this game, but unless you have friends. The servers can be hostile. (especially the TTT and DarkRP servers, you can get pretty paranoid in TTT ) And singleplayer is only so much fun, you really need to be creative to find fun in singleplayer. I'm a bit on the un-creative side so give the game a try yourself, just make sure to bring a friend.
Garry's Mod is not a game. Garry's Mod is all games you can imagine. Endless hours of fun, even more fun when you play with friends.   Garry's Mod is love, Garry's Mod is life.

Pros: +Great ways to be friends with people +Make a helicopter out of a bathtub +Many gamemodes (Zobmie Survival, Slasher, Trouble in Terrorist Town, Hide and Seek, RP, etc.) +Play with physics +Simply the best sandbox game of all time +Almost never ever get bored +Still many players playing +Workshop +Game gives you the stuff to do things, you do the rest.  Cons: -You have to download something from workshop, otherwise the game gets pretty boring. -Community can be mostly annoying on servers -Can get boring if you play on singleplayer. -The game can crash and do other stuff if you download too many mods -Some textures will have errors if you don't have CS: Source.  But other than that, totally recommended! You won't get bored most of the time, many gamemodes, fun way to get steam friends. Definitely recommended!

One day I bought this because it was on sale for about $2.50. I didn't think much of it but then I started playing. I couldn't believe how addicting it was. I started losing sleep and skipping meals. It started to show on my physical health. My family started bugging me about it and even considered putting me into a rehabilitation center. Let's just say they won't be bugging me anymore. But now I dont have the funds to maintain an internet connection. I've sold everything I have just to play. I can't even go to starbucks and use their wifi because I sold my clothes and apparently they dont accept nudity. So basically I'm writing this review from my phone on top of a bridge. My life isn't worth it without this game. Yet it seems to have ruined my life. Goodbye world.   **10/10 buy** Great gift for kids!   (EDIT March 29, 2014) Your comments make me lol. I might as well make a legit review.  Yes I bought this game for only $2.50 but if you ask me, It is so much more worth it. It may not be the most graphical intensive game but I've never had so much fun. It is packed with hundreds of hours of pure laughter and randomness. You never know what you will find in this game. Keep this in mind though, this is a MOD and it is mostly just community made content so it may have it's bugs. But what game doesn't? Only thing I can complain about is the ability of making a joinable server. I never could make one. Oh well, I reccomend this game to anyone and everyone. A true **10/10** game.  P.S. you should probably buy CS:S (Counter Strike: Source) while you're at it. Many of the servers require it. Have fun! Build responsibly.

In all of my grand stupor, I realized I have continually overlooked something without so much as a passing notice: I have never once added this game to any of my favorite games lists. I'm honestly not sure why I haven't; As of the date of this review, I've put in over one-thousand hours on this account, and over four times as much on my old account (that account weighs in at roughly 4500 hours thusfar). Maybe it's the fact that, for whatever reason, I've never really thought of it as a game in its own right. I put countless hours into it in Garry's Mod 9 when it truly still was a modification and purchased Garry's Mod on release on my old account. I've met so many people through this 'game'; I could go so far as to say my life would be incredibly different if it wasn't for my countless hours in this. I've drifted from community to community, spending literal years of my life among different cultures in what amounts to an open book full of tools for a game I've barely clocked even a few hundred hours in at most. My friends, almost all of them, can be attributed, directly or indirectly, to me playing this 'game'. My current and past relationships all were a result from me meeting people or spending time in communities that I had come across while playing this 'game'. My past insecurities, my current strengths, and my place in life can almost all have their roots traced back to me browsing the internet and finding the comic 'Concerned' and picking up the modification used to make that comic.   So, what prevents me from calling this a 'game'? Why is it that, for all of what this creation has offered me, can I still not think of this as a 'game'? Perhaps it is the fact that it truly was never really a game to me. It was a blank slate; it was a whiteboard on which I myself and many others could express themselves creatively and make whatever they could dream of, engine limits notwithstanding. This, this 'game', this modification, this thing has been such a life-altering experience for me. While this may sound ridiculous and childish for most people, I can't express how much gratitude I have for this stupid little free-turned-$10 mod to exist. It gave me better insight into how some things are constructed, it encouraged me to learn how to code and how to script, it started me on the road to server management and website administration, and most of all, it helped fill the void for the years I spent as a teenager upset with my life and brought me some of the closest friends I will ever have. I love this mod, I love this 'game', and I love this stupid simple little broken mess that I still find myself playing for countless hours day after day.   In hindsight, I feel as if I was right about never calling it a game and never listing it on my favorite games list, because for the longest time, it was not a game to me; it was the only thing that kept me going.

After hundreds of hours (and screenshots) in GMod, I think it's time I gave this a more proper review. This is a sandbox game in which anything goes. Want to make a vehicle covered in guns? You can do that. Want to make a goofy screenshot (or screenshots)? You can do that. Want to mow down scientists with an AK-47? You can do that. Want to use hundreds of add-ons that add lots of weapons, ragdolls, tools, etc.? You can do that. Want to sit down and watch a YouTube video in a movie theater (with the right maps and add-ons)? You can do that. Want to pose Kevin Spacey? You can do that. Want to play on a roleplay server and get banned for killing people? You can do that. Want to go to the forums and see a lot of people complaining about FNAF? You could do that... but I would avoid that.  Bottom line: If you want a game where you can just do whatever you want, this is the game for you.

Garry's Mod is a sandbox game.   You have a wide variety of props from various Source games (depending on which you own), and multiple tools at your disposal. With these, you can build different contraptions, make vehicles, construct buildings, etc. As well as all the content included in the game, you can find a ton of mods online via the game's website or Steam Workshop. You can also make/script your own.   But the fun doesn't stop there. Multiplayer is a totally different thing entirely. You can find sandbox servers and build with up to hundreds of other players, or you could dive into one of the many user created game modes. From Hide and Seek to Role Playing, there is a huge variety of unique modes to play.   A few I would recommend are:   Trouble in Terrorist Town.  A group of 'innocent' terrorists must work with the detective(s) to discover who the traitors are and kill them. The traitors must take out the innocents, preferably without alerting anyone else. No one knows who is innocent and who is not, making for a sometimes tense experience.   Morbus.  A group of humans must hold out for a certain amount of time against aliens, or kill them all. There are two types of aliens: Brood aliens, and Swarm aliens. The Brood aliens get upgrades, and can transform into humans. Allowing them to get into groups and pick off people one by one. The Swarm aliens are what players spawn as when they die (assuming they were killed by another Swarm alien, or human). These have a melee and ranged attack, but no upgrades. Their role is to weaken the humans, and try to kill them.  The humans have needs. Every now and then you will have to either sleep, eat, shower, or pee. You cannot move during this time, so must be wary of those around you, in case they are brood aliens.  Overall one of the best game modes. A ton of fun, especially with friends.   DarkRP. DarkRP is one of the more casual RP modes in Gmod. You spawn into the map as a citizen, and can choose a job to play as. From drug dealers to civil protection, there is a wide variety of roles to pick. You can go around earning money, commit crimes, buy and furnish your own house, etc. Great if you find the more serious RP servers to be boring.   If you plan to buy the game, be sure you own Counter-Strike: Source too. A lot of maps use textures from CS:S, and if you do not own it you will see purple and black squares everywhere. I spent about 350 hours experiencing this, and I would not recommend it.   Overall the game is absolutely brilliant. One of the very few that I can keep going back to and not get bored. I purchased the game around 4 years ago for £5.99, and have since put almost 600 hours into it.   One of the best purchases I have ever made.

I'm going to give an introduction to people who have no idea what Garry's mod is and why it's one o the most popular games available on steam. Garry's Mod isn't necessarily a game, it's a tool, it's a tool that the steam community have been able to turnaround and make into a game with servers, game modes, weapons and armour. I personally don't think Face punch are the developers of this game, they gave the community a basis to form their own game. If you get Garry's mod and nothing else, you are probably going to be confused why people like it this much. However, if u get around 10 mods off of the steam workshop, you will see why.  One of the main reasons people love Garry's Mod this much is due to the community mods, it's not the game necessarily but the mods made by the community. Garry's Mod was originally released in 2004 as a mod for Half-Life 2 and escalated in popularity when it was brought onto Steam. A game that was released in 2004 still has 1000s of players going on each day, I have tons of friends that just play Garry's Mod an nothing else on their steam profile, because of the variety this game has.  There's a sandbox mode which is what it is. You can do whatever the hell you want. You can make a zombie apocalypse happen, you can make NPCs into a happy family or you can shoot an NPC in the face. There are online servers dedicated to each of the Garry's Mod game modes so you can play multiplayer in sandbox which furthers the possibilities of what you can do. You can role-play, you can have a death match with your friends there are endless possibilities.  There's Trouble in Terrorist Town which is best to be played with at least 4 players and is not possible to be played with 1 player. There are a group of players in a server, all of them are innocent except for one (depending on how many people are in the server there can be two terrorists and there can also be one detective who can examine a corpse and determine information about him) the terrorists' goal is to kill all the innocent without being suspected and not to be killed by the innocent. The innocents' goal is to stay alive for 5 minutes and find the terrorist and kill them. I personally don't play much of TTT mainly due to neither me or my friends having a mic but if you have a group of friends with a mic, this game is perfect.  My personal favourite game mode is Prop Hunt. There are two teams, Hunters and Props. The Props are given 30 seconds to disguise themselves as props and hide in the map. After 30 seconds, the Hunters are released and they are given 4 minutes and 30 seconds to find all of the props. There's something about Prop Hunt which I find addicting. I always find achieved and feel like I outsmarted someone when I'm on either of the team. If you feel like you aren't accomplishing anything in life, give Prop Hunt a try.  Another game mode that I've spent a lot of time on is death run. There are two teams (again), the Deaths and the Runners.The runners are unleashed upon a map and their goal is to get to the end. However there are traps hidden around the map which the Deaths need to activate to prevent the Runners from reaching the end. I found this game to probably be the most frustrating out of all of the game modes as I kept on dying half the time because of my own stupidity and not because of the traps. I only recommend that you play death run if you're experienced at Garry's m=Mod as there are a few things in death run that inexperienced players won't understand how to do.  There's also Hide and Seek which is self explanatory. There are two teams, the hiders and the seekers, the hiders need to hide in the environment and the seekers have a certain amount of time to find all of the hiders. This is a bit like prop hunt but it's harder, when in prop hunt the 'Hiders' could disguise themselves as props and blend in with the environment and the 'seekers' had a full arsenal of weapons, in Hide and Seek, the Hiders won't be able to blend in with the environment and the Seekers don't have any weapons to kill the hiders with, they need to chase them and catch up with them. I only recommend this if you're finding Prop Hunt either boring, tedious or you're sick of winning each time as if you are still enjoying Prop Hunt there isn't much else here, it's only for the players that want a bit more of a challenge.  The next game mode is Murder. Murder is basically like TTT but harder. In Murder there are two teams, Bystanders and the Murderer. The Murderer is given a knife and they need to kill everyone with it and the bystanders are defenceless except for one of them that has a Magnum revolver. Their goal is to figure out who is the murderer and the person who has the gun needs to shoot and kill the murderer. Similar to Hide and Seek, I only recommend this to people who are getting sick of TTT or are finding it too easy as if you're enjoying TTT there won't be anything here for you.  The last game mode that I'm going to talk about is Jailbreak. This is basically like the Minecraft mod Cops and Robbers, There are two teams, the Prisoners and the Officers and one of the officers is the Warden. The prisoners' goal is to escape the prison, which will take about 10 minutes or to kill all of the officers. The officers goal is to keep the prisoners in check and stop them from leaving the prison and they win if all of the prisoners are all either dead or if they're still in the prison after the time limit has expired. This one is a breath of fresh air as this one has cooperation involve with it, it isn't necessarily every man for himself, the prisoners have to work together in order to escape the prison and the officers have to work together to keep the prisoners in check. I recommend this game mode to anyone getting GMod or anyone who has gotten it.  I've just scraped the tip of the iceberg as there are tons of other game modes in GMod I haven't talked about like, Base Wars (a game where you defend your own base) and Zombie Survival (a game where you need to survive a zombie apocalypse.) If I have not convinced you to pick up GMod then I fail at being a reviewer. Just get GMod and enjoy it for what it is along with 1000s of other players.  Pros  + Good graphics + Tons of fun to be had + Replay value even 10 years after it's original release + Addicitng + Something for nearly everyone  Cons  Final verdict: 9/10  My steam curator group:  http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MellowReviews

Garry's Mod is the kind of game that you just can't explain and can't quite even put into any catagory but its own. I have been playing Garry's Mod for 5 years now and with the current hours I have now, it shows I put 1 hour and 45 minutes into the game everyday for the past 5 years. It feels like you can do anything. One day you can be a counter-terrorist in the midst of a town of 'innocent' terrorists and find sadistic ways to kill them all secretly. The next you can be a mob boss in a group of your friends as you try to take over the city from the government in a dark roleplay gamemode. After that you can imserse yourself in the essence of a glass bottle trying to flee from the hunters who wish only to break you. Or be in a remenant of humanity defending yourself from a hoard of zombies in a fight for survival. This doesnt even cover half of what you can do in the game as I havent even mentioned all the diffrent forms of roleplay from being a clone in The Grand Army of the Republic or a occupying member of The Heer in 1942. And this still isnt even the end of it and I havent even meantioned all the great people you will meet from playing the game and all the friends and bonds you'll make. There is no possible way to 'beat' Garry's Mod. The only beating you will do is beating yourself up for not buying it sooner. To put it simply, theres something for everyone in Garry's Mod, and its one of the greatest games ever made.

If you're looking for a positive review, then you're in the wrong place, HOWEVER, if you're here for a tremendous chicken Stir Fry recipe, THEN LOOK NO FURTHER!  - Serves 4 - 10 mins to prepare and 10 mins to cook - 325 calories / serving - Healthy  INGREDIENTS:  - 1 orange, zested and juiced - 2tbsp soy sauce - 2tbsp sesame oil - 250g (8oz) tender stem broccoli - 5cm (2in) piece root ginger - 1tbsp sunflower oil - 1 garlic clove, finely sliced - 1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced - 150g Straight To Wok Noodles - 400g (13oz) chicken fillet, cut into thin slices  METHOD  Step 1 - Mix together the orange zest and juice, soy sauce and sesame oil and set aside.  Step 2 - Blanch the broccoli in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain well and set aside.  Step 3 - Finely shred the ginger. Then heat a large frying pan or wok, add the sunflower oil, heat it until sizzling, and fry the ginger till it's crisp.  Step 4 - When it's done, remove with a slotted spoon. Add the chicken and garlic, and stir-fry until just browned. Remove the meat using a slotted spoon and set aside.  Step 5 - Add the red pepper and broccoli and stir-fry for around 2-3 minutes until it's just tender. Add the soy sauce mixture, bring it to the boil then return the chicken to the pan and heat through. Serve with noodles.

Amazing game, but remember, it's only as good as the addons you put into it. The very basic singleplayer itself is fun, but lacking in parts as a sandbox game. However, this can be fixed by a quick visit to the workshop, where you will be able to find virtually any addon you wish. Do you want to parachute out of a Black Hawk while quickscoping Osama bin Laden in the head? You can do that. Do you want to nuke a base made completely out of couches, during a slow mo sequence? That is also possible. There are also many multiplayer servers, ranging from sandbox, to Roleplay, to TDM, or to Trouble in Terrorist Town. Virtually every sort of multiplayer experience possible is in this game. The multiplayer games have themes like Zombie survival, or military life, and arcade deathmatch. However, it should also be noted, there are MANY bugs. While these bugs are virtually non existant in vanilla singleplayer, you WILL encounter them once you download some addons. Having many addons will slow down the game load speed, if you're on a low-end computer. 9/10.

My hours. help.  I wrote something for real!  These hours are legit, I played this game a lot in the past to avoid some tragic stuff in real life. I was young and didn't really have my gaming consoles anymore because of my brothers and I had a really bad pc, which i still own. TF2 was one of the games i could play pretty well on this pc but with horrid graphics, but it was one of the more fun games I installed. I met some real cool and nice people on this game as well as people who i plan to keep by my side. The community back then was more humble compared to nowadays. You have competitive gamers who spam their bind keys with unfunny/gross jokes and very obnoxious people who are either yelling at you or telling you to do specific things to win the game. When really, it doesn't even matter if you win or lose. However, you also have those people who are really awesome and you may meet some nice friends along the way! Although you never know what kinda person you're going to meet on this game. In my honest opinion, if you want to have a game to just waste time on (and money) or just mess around with people you know (which is what I do now), this is perfect. Esspecially the mann vs. machine co-op. I mainly play that now. Although to me, the game lost its touch, update wise, and I moved onto other games.   I believe it's worth a shot to try it out but other than that, I'd keep it as a casual game. I don't think the competitive scene is worth getting into anymore because it's being flooded by crude people. Atleast from my experiance after over about 4+ years of playing it just got worse and worse. You will eventually be tied into drama even if you try to avoid it. You'll be more stressed than actually having fun, I'll tell you that!  Although in all seriousness, this game is losing its touch and probably isn't worth making it your main game MAINLY because the updates they've been releasing are becoming very dull and not as great as they used to be. BUT, it's a great game to just play to pass the time and have fun! All you'll really notice nowdays is...people really love to trade more than actually play. Living off as a free to play would be very tough and you'd need to be patient with items you would want, unless you got that MONEY! Hope this helps.   One last thing, I am not saying this game is bad in any way. I am saying that it's worth trying and playing with friends, or even meeting people! Although there are some downsides that you won't like, such as some stuff I pointed out above. Strictly towards the community. I personally think you should have this game as a side game rather than your come home to play sorta thing. Have it as a once in a while game, because it's nothing to be big about, unless you really do not like most of the millions of other games out there.   Just give it a shot and see what you think! Have fun <3

The vicious cycle of Team fortress 2  First when you'll arrive in the game, you'll want Weapons, tons of them.  Then you'll see that everyone has hats, and you'll want these, a tons of them.  Then you'll realize that hats doesn't matter, only skill count, so you'll want a lot of skills, tons of them.  Then new weapons will be added, and you'll want them, all of them.  Then a new hat will be added and you'll want it, cause it'll be fancy on your main class.  Then you'll realize again, that you don't give a damn about hats, all is about is skill.  Then when you have waited for 3 years, new weapons will be added, and you'll want them.  And then you realize that you spent like 2000 hours of your life for this, met great friends, and you'll have a server where's you feeling like home, and you discovered so much things via the community, it learnt you so much.  Then the rude reality of life, bring you on earth, and this game is here, Waiting for you to play 1,2,3... hours, and you'll be happy to see that all your good friend are still there.
